characters: WILKES AT THE FRONT OF THE SANCTUARY.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: And the white glow becomes blue sky, and we FIND the tip church steeple reaching to heaven. And as we WIDEN we see that it’s attached to a small, white clapboard church somewhere in the suburbs of a big city. A SIGN out front tells us where we are and the late-model cars parked out front tell us when: the early 1990s. And as the CAMERA continues its move, we settle on a WHITE ROSE in the f.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which becomes an entire BOUQUET of WHITE ROSES. And then CAMERA will carry us to soft CLOSE UPS of a wedding cerem in progress: SUNLIGHT streaming in an stained glass window and pointin an ornate cross on a church wall. The lapel of a tuxedo jacket, adorned with a tie made of colorful African fabric. The beautiful train of a wedding gown surrounded by white rose petals on the red carpet. Two black hands, one soft and feminine, and one masculine athletic lighting a unity candle. An open Bible in a strong BLACK MINISTER’S hands. A handkerchief wiping tears from old black eyes in the audience. A glistening diamond ring is slipped by the masculine han onto a soft, feminine finger. Two pairs of moist lips meet in a passionate kiss. As the SONG ENDS, we’1ll WIDEN from the kiss to reveal handsome, sturdily-built, tuxedoed DAVE JOHNSON, probably embracing his gorgeous, not-much-younger bride, CLARICE C JOHNSON. And as they hold their kiss for what seems like long, we see that we are in a nicely appointed sanctuary filled with happy, mostly black WEDDING GUESTS. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fade hairstyles on the men and Anita Baker bobs on th women date us to the early 1990s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all presided over by larger-than-life BISHOP WIL dressed in ministerial robes with colorful Afrocentric accents. He taps Dave on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP WILKES
dialogues.text: How about saving some for the honeymoon, brother? Dave and Clarice break their clutch, slightly embarrassed and the audience erupts in LAUGHTER and a few HOOTS and HOLLAS from some of the men, including handsome, young Be Man BROCK HOUSEMAN, the lone Caucasian member of the wedd party. And he’s the got an all-business-up-front-party-in back mullett going for him, which puts him right out of college, and not yet quite legit. Dave and Clarice now turn to face the Bishop. He smiles a them broadly and holds up his Bible again.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP WILKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dave... Clarice, before I present you as husband and wife, there’s one last lesson I want to leave with you as you begin your life together. A wise king named Solomon once said this: (reading from Bible) “It is better to have a partner than go through life alone. Share the work, share the wealth, for if one falls down, the other is there to pick him up. But pity the man who falls and has no one by his side. And in bed, two can warm each other at night. But one alone, shivers all night long. By yourself, you are unprotected. But with a partner you can face the worst the world has to offer. But even better is a cord of three strands because it is not easily broken.” (beat, closing his Bible) My brother, my sister... I’1l be honest with you. Life is gonna do its best to beat you up. And it’s hard to keep the good in a good marriage when bad things happen. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bishop then retrieves a gold-colored, braided cord, a places one end around Dave’s shoulders and then drapes th other end around Clarice’s shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP WILKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is a three-stranded cord. The two of you represent the first two strands, but God represent the third. And as long as you stay close to God and His family, I promise your marriage will be a three-stranded cord that nothing in this world can break. And as Dave and Clarice nod that they understand the admonition, we’ll FIND Clarice’s 50-something, very stron willed mother, MARY CLARK, or MAMA as we will come to kno her, sitting all by herself in the front row. And she’s watching these proceedings with uncertain, skeptical eyes And we'll PRELAP the smooth sounds of BLACK wedding DJ an the end of some R & B number like “AIN’T NO WAY.”

dialogues.speaker: DJ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: All right, give it up for sister Aretha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place has been decorated for a wedding reception. Tables, linens, disco ball and rotund DJ with his sound system set up in front of a dance floor packed with guest including Bishop Wilkes, who is mixing it up with his WIF

dialogues.speaker: DJ
dialogues.text: Step aside, peeps. DJ Supersize comin’ at you now with a special dance request. The wedding guests begin clearing the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: DJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Time for the bride’s own mama, Mrs. Mary Clark, to step on the floor with her new son-in-law. Mama smiles coyly as she takes to the floor. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DJ CONT'D
dialogues.text: (suggestively) Lord have mercy, Mrs. Clark. Could you be my mama... ‘cuz I love the way you cookin’ tonight. Which draws HOOTS and HOWLS from across the hall. She wav him off with mock humility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the edge of the crowd, Dave is standing with his new b and his best man Brock, with whom he trades a hesitant lo

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Oh, damn.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: (rolling her eyes) Please. She ain’t gonna bite you. Dave starts moving sheepishly out onto the floor. Brock calls after him and doing his best Vanilla Ice impression

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: I got your back, dawg. Clarice elbows Brock in the ribs as Dave joins Mama to th APPLAUSE of the wedding guests.

dialogues.speaker: DJ
dialogues.text: This one goes out to all you mamas. From my man, Babyface. Mama plasters on a smile and puts her arms around Dave's neck. He puts his hands appropriately around her waist, a the DJ throws the switch on a tune like “SONG FOR MY MAMA And they dance together for a long moment as Clarice and of her bridesmaids watch, their emotions brimming over th beautiful scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama pulls in close and begins to talk in hushed tones to Dave, her manufactured smile never leaving her face.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: Welcome to the family, baby.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mrs. Clark. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: (admonishingly) Boy, I know you did not just call me “Mrs. Clark.” I expect you to call me “Mama.” Just like I expect you and my Reesie at my house every week for Sunday dinner.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (taken aback) Yes, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: Just like I expect you to learn how to hold a job, keep food on the table, and stay away from all them ghetto-pass-carryin’, crack-dealin’ street hustlers you used to run with. I don’t care if you did graduate from college, I will not see my baby girl have anything less than the life she deserves.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: No, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: And one more thing. You a man, so you probably can’t help yourself, but if I ever catch you puttin’ your eyes on some little Miss Thang who ain’t my daughter, I will personally come over there like Jesus and pluck them out. Are you feelin’ me? A shell-shocked Dave looks at her for a long moment. Ther a lot he would like to say, but he thinks better of it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I feel you. Mama's smile says that’s exactly how she wants it to be. Just then, Clarice taps her mother on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: My turn, Mama.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: Yes, it is, baby. (patting Dave on cheek) This boy and me gonna get along just fine. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that, Mama moves off into the crowd. As Clarice Dave begin to dance, the DJ transitions us into Lionel Richie’s “THREE TIMES A LADY.” Clarice notices that Dave a little shaken by his encounter with Mama.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I know Mama can come on a little strong.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: More like a Mack truck.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: She just wants the best for me.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: (smiling seductively) But she ain’t comin’ where we goin’ tonight. Which quickly snaps Dave out of his funk.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Did I mention how good you look in that dress?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Yes. But do you know how good I’m gonna look out of it?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (eyes heaven gratefully) Thank you, Jesus. And as they share an expectation of intimacy that only a groom and bride can share, Clarice will pull Dave into a kiss. And suddenly, it will be as if they are all alone i the world, with space and time SPINNING AROUND THEM. And will begin to hear Dave’s REMEMBERING VOICE as the song continues to play.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When I was growing up on my Granny’s knee, we were poor as church mice. Scratch that. The church mice were the rich ones. We were the church rats. But it didn’t matter because Granny raised me to know right from wrong. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And before she passed on, God rest her soul, she worked her fingers to the bone makin’ sure I could get out the hood, makin’ sure I could be a college boy. And she was the only woman I ever worshipped until the day I met a young lady in college who could make Halle Berry want to eat her heart out.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE V.O.
dialogues.text: Clarice was the most beautiful woman I had ever laid eyes on. And together we were goin’ places in this world. Someday, she was gonna be the Donald Trump of Dallas, and I was gonna coach Longhorn basketball. This was a lady a brother would go to war for. A lady a man could pledge to be faithful to, and yes, to keep his eyes from getting plucked out for. C) CLARICE SHOWING HER ENGAGEMENT RING TO HER GAL-PALS.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As Bishop Wilkes, my childhood pastor, had said... she was a woman to have and to hold, and to cherish until you breathe your last.

dialogues.speaker: E
dialogues.text: WITH THE “JUST MARRIED” HANGING OFF THE BACK END.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And that’s exactly what I did. On our wedding night, it was me, Clarice and a little bit of heaven. And we didn’t come up for air for two days. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: With all your hopes and plans and dreams right out in front of you like that, the honeymoon can last forever. G) DAVE AND CLARICE POSING IN FRONT A “JUST SOLD” REAL ES SIGN IN FRONT OF A SMALL BUNGALOW -- THEIR FIRST HOME.

dialogues.speaker: H
dialogues.text: MAMA IN HER HOUSE. AND WE’LL PUSH IN ON DAVE’S FORCED SMI

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: INT. DAVE’S PANEL VAN - DAY - TRAVELING (PRESENT DAY) We’re still CLOSE ON Dave, only now he looks a dozen year older in a work shirt that marks him as working class. A more worry lines around the eyes. A few gray hairs dustin his temples. And somehow “THREE TIMES A LADY” never quit playing. In fact we’re now hearing it on the car radio. B as Dave drives along, he is deep in thought. On the other side of the boulevard, a Police cruiser zoom past, its SIREN WAILING, pulling Dave out of his thoughts He inadvertently flips the radio dial to a NEWSTALK stati

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But just like the Bishop said, life has a way of knocking the hell out of you. We’1ll PULL OUTSIDE the van far enough to read the sign o side of his truck. “ALL-PRO JANITORIAL & CARPET CLEANING.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Dave’s van pulls into the driveway of a nice, upper middl class home in a neighborhood full of similar homes. (This not the starter home we saw them buy, but a step up into suburbs). A recent model Cadillac V-Series is already sitting in the driveway, with one of those magnetic signs plastered on the door: “HASTINGS PROPERTIES & REAL ESTATE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice, still looking as girlishly trim and put-together she did on her wedding day, is noshing on a salad at a si bar in the well-appointed kitchen while reading House Beautiful magazine. She’s dressed smartly in a sexy blous and skirt as Dave enters. He brightens when he sees her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Damn, girl. All those curves and me with no brakes.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Hey, baby. Dave crosses over, moves in for a kiss. But she turns her cheek to him.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry. I just touched up my face. Dave shrugs it off. Gives her a peck on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How was your day? Dave opens the fridge, and pops the top on a bottle of be

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I had to do the bank building myself because two of my boys called in sick. I tell you, Reesie, why I let you talk me into starting my own business I’m still trying to figure out.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: (slightly irritated) Baby, we been over all this. Coaching JV football wasn’t puttin’ us in this zip code. You just got to do a better job of hiring the right people. Dave has heard this lecture before and Clarice can see he tired of it. She softens her approach.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Besides, you think I want my big, strong chocolate kiss waxin’ floors for a livin’? I want you in the executive suite where you deserve to be. Dave gives her a reluctant smile. The sweets worked.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I know, Boo. He comes around behind her. Starts massaging her shoulder (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whaddya say we forget all that nonsense tonight and get us little quality time? She melts a little at his touch, but remembers her job.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Oh, that sounds so good. But I got to show houses tonight.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: What about tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: That’s no good either. It’s my real estate board dinner. You promised to sit with Mama while I sit up at the main table, remember?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (blanching at reminder) Oh, shit, that’s right.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: (looks at him askance) I know I did not hear you cussin’ in this house about Mama. Clarice puts on her colorful real-estate blazer.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I tell you what. If you show Mama a nice time, somebody gonna get his freak on Saturday night. She nibbles on his ear a little. Dave’s jelly. Clarice knows it. Right where she wants him.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘1l even throw in one of those lacy numbers that gets you all weak in the knees. Dave looks her in the eye, hopefully.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Maybe we could also... you know... talk about the future.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Let’s not go there, baby. You know I’m not ready for that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She gives him another peck on the cheek and exits. His countenance falls as he watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: As we SWOOP DOWN over Dallas after dark, it’s all glass a prisms of light, especially in the priciest piece of real estate in town, the 40-story Trinity View condo building. INT. BROCK HOUSEMAN’S DOWNTOWN CONDO - NIGHT We’re CLOSE ON the timer of fancy blender whose jar conta water and some kind of protein powder. The timer hits 6:1 p.m. and the machine suddenly whirs to life, blending up contents into some kind of green health drink. And we'll WIDEN to see that we are in a gourmet kitchen i very upscale bachelor condo with skyrise views on three sides. The place looks like a Bang & Olufsen store threw -- leather furniture, modern art, giant plasma screen TV the wall and all the digital trappings. At that moment, the front door opens and Brock Houseman enters, looking as fit and handsome as ever, his college- mullett replaced with close-cropped George Clooney hair. throws off his expensive suit coat and loosens a tie as h crosses over to his telephone on the kitchen counter. He punches in a phone number, then his voice-mail code, a puts the phone to his ear as he pours his smoothie into a glass and begins chugging as he listens.

dialogues.speaker: COMPUTER VOICE, (OVER PHONE)
dialogues.text: Four new messages... He punches a key to listen.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE
dialogues.text: (flirty and sexy) Hey, Cowboy, it’s Vickie. It’s been too long since the last time we hooked up. I got the hot tub heating up in case you’re lonely tonight. Brock gulps weakly and steels his courage.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Stay strong, bro. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He pushes a key and we hear the ERASE tone. Then the next message begins to play.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER FEMALE VOICE, (OVER PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hi, sweetie pie, this is Mom. Are you getting my messages? Something must be wrong with your system. Anyway, my friend Sophie has this really lovely niece who sings in the church choir and you won’t believe what she does for a living -- she’s a professional bowler. Isn’t that fun? Anyway, I thought maybe I could have the two of you over for dinner Friday and -- Brock sighs and punches to ERASE the message.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mom, I’m having my finger nails ripped out that night. And then yet one more feminine voice comes on the line.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE, (OVER PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hi, Brock... this is Partygirl 229 Remember me from Singles Chat-dot- com? I got your number from Surferdude 102 who it got it froma friend of his who knows how to track people down. I was thinking we could meet for drinks and -- Brock punches the ERASE button, looks at the phone horrif

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Okay, now I’m officially scared. Finally a voice he wants to hear comes on the line.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (OVER PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yo, B, it’s Dave. Reesie’s working tonight. If your lawyer ass ain't too busy, what do you say we get our hoops on? Holler back at me. Brock smiles, relieved, as he hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: (like a black guy) Now that’s what I’m talking about.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: We’re HIGH and WIDE on an imposing downtown hospital with heavy Catholic influence on the facade. As we PUSH IN, we FIND an ambulance parked at the emergency entrance. And j at that moment, its SIRENS and LIGHTS come on and it peel away from the hospital on its way to only God knows where

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re CLOSE ON a bare leg with a fresh surgical scar at t knee joint engaged in a knee-extension exercise, and WIDE see an OLDER MALE PATIENT painfully raising his leg as a pretty, perky physical therapist in her early 30s coaches through it. She is not a stone fox, but Meg Ryan sexy -- despite the perspiration on her brow and the fatigue of a long shift in a busy PT clinic

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Just a few more, Jerry. Before you know it, you’ll have that new bionic knee out on the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MALE PATIENT
dialogues.text: It hurts like hell. (mischievous smile) Maybe you could kiss it and make it better.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: (rolls eyes, teasingly) Behave yourself. She calls to a passing PT ASSISTANT.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Electrical stim, then ice for Mister Hound Dog here. (smiling at Jerry) On second thought, no stimulation. He’s already had enough of that. Julie trades another smile and a wink with Leonard as the Assistant takes over for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACK Julie over to the bullpen where she hands Jerry’s c to a middle-aged, humorless-looking OFFICE SUPERVISOR.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, Nick, who’s my next victim? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The supervisor just stares at her -- flatly.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was a joke. That would be where I say something funny and you make this little noise called a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: We got a memo from corporate.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: What'd it say? They taking away our vending machine? No more Little Debbies at snack break? He hands her the memo. Her smile fades as she reads it.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Part time? Are you kidding me? The patient load is higher than it’s ever been.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Costs are up. We're going to have to figure out a way to see same number of clients in half the time.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Cheap-frigging-HMO. What’s next -- instead of Viagra, a Popsicle stick and duct tape?

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Julie. I don’t know what to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I’m raising a 12-year-old son. How do I replace this income?

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Look, you’re my best therapist. I’1l try to throw some freelance work your way.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Don’t bother. I’11 just sell one of my organs. Who needs two kidneys anyway? She throws up her hands in frustration and crosses out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shiny black BMW with high performance tires pulls into and Clarice’s driveway and HONKS its horn. From inside, s clean-enough-for-radio RAP SONG from a high-end sound sys INT. BROCK’S BMW - NIGHT - MOMENT LATER Brock, now dressed in ratty gym clothes, is sitting in th car, RAPPING along with the song throbbing on the Blaupun when the passenger door opens and Dave slides in. He’s al wearing sweats, and carrying a basketball. Brock offers h fist to Dave for a knuckle-bump.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: (loudly over Rap song) What up, D... how you doin’? Dave can hardly hear him over the radio.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Hey, Grandmaster Flash, you wanna chill the jams before one of my white neighbors has a heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Sorry, bro. My bad. Brock turns down the volume. Dave chuckles as Brock backs car out of the driveway. This sort of black/white reparte is obviously something that’s part of their friendship. INT. BROCK’S BMW - TRAVELING - NIGHT - A MOMENT LATER They have now left Dave’s neighborhood and are proceeding toward downtown, the skyline closing in out the window.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Glad you called me tonight, man.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Saved from another lonely night in that million-dollar penthouse, huh?

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: It’s two million, but who’s counting? Besides, I could be hitting it with any number of ladies if I wanted to. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BROCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m just taking a little break right now to get my head straight, you know what I’m saying? Long as I got my “Good Times” reruns, it’s all good. Dave doesn’t know whether to laugh... or be weirded out.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Tell me you do not watch “Good Times.”

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: I love that show. It reminds me of when I was just a shorty living in the ghet-to.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Please. A white trash trailer park ain’t no ghetto.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: (winking at Dave) I know, but I’m just trying to keep it real for my main homey, ya'll.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (chuckling) Has anybody ever told you that you are one strange Caucasian?

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: (dropping black patois) This coming from a black guy who lives in the whitest neighborhood in the city. Brock smiles, offers his palm. Dave has to give him some skin on that one. These guys have a real bond.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: A classy real estate office building with lovely landscap and a sign matching the magnetic placard on Clarice’s Cadillac, which is just now pulling into a parking spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Clarice enters, she is instantly waylaid by MICHELLE her sassy, brassy, late-20s black assistant who has opini on every subject and is not shy about sharing them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: Okay, girlfriend, here’s the four- one-one. She hands Clarice a file folder and points through a wind into her office where an upscale, professional-looking bl couple, THE REIDS, are waiting.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Superior Court Judge in there is married to Miz chi chi art dealer and they are looking to get up into a new zip code.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Where do they want to look?

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: Hillwood.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: That's a nice zip code.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: Go get the money, sister girl. We about to get paid. Clarice gets a wry smile. And she crosses into her office

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Mr. and Mrs. Reid, I’m Clarice Johnson. So nice to meet you. And we begin HEARING some jam like 50 Cent’s “PLACES TO G

dialogues.speaker: BASKETBALL
dialogues.text: As it SLAMS THROUGH THE NET, and then WIDEN to see we’re an inner-city gymnasium in the middle of a shirts-and-ski pick-up basketball game. Dave comes down hard, having just slammed-dunked the ball over a tatted-up, street-looking black dude in his 30s we come to know as DARNELL GOODEN. Dave thumps his bare, sweaty, chiseled chest proudly and exchanges high-fives w bare-chested Brock and then a couple of his other African American TEAMMATES. Darnell is fuming.

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: That was charging, dawg! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Gimme the lane if you don’t want my foot in your hind parts, homey. (motions for the ball) Ball! Darnell casts an angry look at Dave. One of the other players chunks the ball to Dave who takes it to the basel Dave takes the ball in, tossing it to one of his teammate really BIG DUDE with a perpetual smile, and we’ll TRACK h as he begins dribbling the ball down court as Darnell and team get back on defense. And for a long time, it’s all passes and shiny bodies slamming into one another. And th Dave gets the ball back and sees Brock in the open in thr point territory. And the action we’ll STROBE into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A) Dave fires a chest past to Brock. B) Darnell sees what’s happening and moves into action. C) As Brock goes up for his shot, a black fist flies INTO FRAME and connects with his face -- hard. D) Brock slams to the floor and the ball goes rolling out bounds, and we'll be overtaken by REAL TIME once again. Brock jumps to his feet, blood gushing from his nose, and immediately charges Darnell. And soon they are a whirling dervish of flying kicks and punches, and Dave and some of other players immediately rush in to break it up.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yo, knock it off! Break it up! Finally Dave and a teammate are able to pry them apart an Brock and Darnell both come out of the tussle spitting ma

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: (glaring at Darnell) What the hell was that, man?

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: (thrusts a finger at Dave) Nigger wanted street rules.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You better check yourself, brother. You ain’t in the prison yard no more! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rage fills Darnell’s eyes and he suddenly charges Dave, pinning him to the wall before Brock and the others can p them apart. Dave is quaking with frustration, disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is your problem, fool?

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: You, college boy, strollin’ up in here with your suburb-livin,’ white ass-kissin’ nose in the air... (pointing at Brock) --. bringin’ this lil’ Jimmy Crack Corn which you. Dave flares at this and trades an uncomfortable look with Brock, but thinks better of fanning the flames.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Come on, brother, we homeys from way back. Why you got to sweat me like that?

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: You used to be good people when you wasn’t too good for the hood. But forget this shit! I ain’t rollin’ with no Uncle Tom! Darnell picks up the ball and fires it to the Big Dude, w no longer has a smile. Darnell starts to walk off. Brock tries one last appeal.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Let’s just finish the game, Darnell. No harm, no foul.

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: (turning back, glaring) Shut up, punk! Go back to Starbucks! With that, Darnell is out of there, leaving nothing but frustrated looks all around, especially from Dave and Bro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re in the beautiful, elegantly appointed foyer of a suburban mini-mansions. Clarice enters with The Reids fro the living room and we TRACK them as they move through. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Reid 20.

dialogues.speaker: MR. REID
dialogues.text: I assume the sellers are looking for full price?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: We can try, but I doubt they’1l come down from one-point-seven.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. REID
dialogues.text: Nor should they. I love the balance and harmony of this place. It has perfect Feng Shui.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Right down to the warm earth tones and east-facing front door.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. REID
dialogues.text: I’m glad we have the same tastes.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: (smiles, gratified) Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: MR. REID
dialogues.text: If you ask me, it all sounds like mumbo-jumbo. rolls her eyes and shares a smile with Clarice.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: My husband said just about the same thing when we were picking out our home. I think the term he used was... “load of bull.”

dialogues.speaker: MR. REID
dialogues.text: (chuckling) Good man. What line of work he in? Catching Clarice off guard. She has to think how to answe Mrs. Reid

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Oh, he... uh... runs his own building management firm.

dialogues.speaker: MR. REID
dialogues.text: Tell him I like the way he thinks.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: (averting his eyes) I will. grabs her by the elbow and starts up the stairs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. REID
dialogues.text: Come on, Clarice. I wanna see how my chi flows in the master bedroom. And the two of them head upstairs, Clarcie’s confident sm returning. And we’ll PRELAP the sound of a coach’s WHISTL

dialogues.speaker: A DIVING BODY
dialogues.text: The lean, young body belongs to 12-year-old BRYSON SAWYER he knifes into the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we now know we are watching a 50-meter freestyle race between several adolescent boys in an Olympic-size pool i outdoor swim stadium with bleachers and stadium lights lighting up the night sky.

dialogues.speaker: ANGLE
dialogues.text: Bryson hits the opposite wall a half-length behind the leader, but coming out of his flip turn, he turns on the afterburners and easily zooms into the lead. He hits the wall in first place, a length ahead of the next best swim And a mother’s shrill voice pierces the air.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Whoo-hoo! Bryson! You-da-man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bryson climbs out of the pool, we can see he’s a good- looking kid with an innocent face. He looks up to see his mother, Julie Sawyer, rushing over with a towel. He looks over at some of the other teenage swimmers, whose mothers pulling similar stunts. They all look completely humiliat

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Way to go, Sweetheart! You rock!

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: Mom, stop. It’s embarrassing you slobbering all over me like this.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Oh, excuse me for gettin’ a little worked up because my twelve-year- old son just cleaned the clocks of a pool full of high school freshmen. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Buster, you won’t ever be too big for your speedos for me to love on you. Got it?

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: (sighs, impatient) Fine. Julie grabs his chin and forces him to look her in the ey

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: And why is that?

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: Can we do this later?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Nope. Give it to me. He rolls his eyes, then quietly gives her the response sh wants -- a routine they clearly have been through many ti

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: Because it’s just you and me, Mom. Her eyes glisten with love.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: That’s right, baby. Just you and me against the world. Their moment is interrupted by COACH SPINELLO, a thick, g looking man in his late-twenties.

dialogues.speaker: COACH SPINELLO
dialogues.text: Hey, Bryson, nice heat. Got any idea what your time was?

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Around twenty-three seconds?

dialogues.speaker: COACH SPINELLO
dialogues.text: Try twenty-one and nine-tenths.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: Whoa.

dialogues.speaker: COACH SPINELLO
dialogues.text: You’re dang-right-whoa. That’s a high school varsity time, bro. Bryson looks at his mother, amazed. She beams. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I’m not saying anything, Coach. I’m supposed to keep my trap shut.

dialogues.speaker: COACH SPINELLO
dialogues.text: (smiles, then) So how do you feel about adding the relay on Saturday? I want you to swim the free-style leg with the fourteen-year-olds.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: (as in “totally cool”) That would be totally ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: COACH SPINELLO
dialogues.text: I’ll take that as a “yes.” (turns to go, then remembers something) Oh, Mrs. Sawyer... ?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Miss Sawyer.

dialogues.speaker: COACH SPINELLO
dialogues.text: Sorry. The team mom asked me to remind you we still need your check for the new club warm-up suits.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Completely slipped my mind. I’11 bring one Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: COACH SPINELLO
dialogues.text: Sounds great. The coach bumps knuckles with Bryson and crosses off. Bry gives Julie a probing look. But she switches gears on him

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: You know what I’m in the mood for? Burger Cabana. But as she busies herself with packing up his stuff, he k his eye on her. That check thing bothers him.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. BROCK’S BMW - TRAVELING - NIGHT They guys are chillin’ with Gatorade and the windows down they drive back from the Y in Brock’s sweet ride. But Dav is clearly still fuming about his run-in on the court. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I’ve known Darnell from knee-high to a Pontiac. I don’t know why he has to do me like that. Brock looks at Dave and smiles knowingly. They’ve had thi conversation before.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Seems pretty simple to me. You stole his college scholarship and he’s still ticked off about it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I didn’t steal nothing from nobody. The brother got caught dealin’ crack and lost his scholarship. I earned mine fair and square.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Still, I know how he feels... being the better athlete and all. Dave gives him a look of disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Better athlete, my ass. Now you the one smoking crack. Brock smiles. Dave knows he’s been had.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Somehow it all got messed up. Two shorties knockin’ around the hood, dreamin’ about being Michael Jordan. One ends up a broke-ass bail-jumper. The other one ends up gettin’ a piece of the pie.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Victim of his circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Shit, that ain’t circumstances, that’s choices. Circumstances is tidal waves and hurricanes. Choices is “Should I or shouldn’t I sling this crack?” (winking at Brock) “Should I or shouldn’t I punch this white Superstar in the nose?” (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: No, circumstances is having no father around to teach you how not to smoke crack because the government forgot to fix the levies and a hurricane just flooded your house. You got to have boots to have bootstraps, brother.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Look at you, all white and liberal and trippin’ like you a member of the Rainbow Coalition. Brock has to laugh about this.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: I guess you’re right. Life isn’t fair. Otherwise, some butt-ugly sucker like you doesn’t end up with a fine lady like Clarice while a rich, handsome dude like me is till trollin’ singles bars. Dave gets his chuckle on.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: No, you a troll ‘cause you afraid of commitment.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: True.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Besides, I ain’t playing any violins for you, Vanilla Ice. (smile fades a little) Married life ain’t all that anyway. Brock looks at him or a long moment. Dave reali

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? You guys are doing great, right? zes he said that out loud, pulls it back.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Yeah, we good. Things is good. Brock stews on that a beat, decides to probe a little dee (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: How’s that other thing between you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (avoiding his eyes) It’s all good. We working on it. But the look on Brock’s face says he isn’t buying it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Brock’s BMW passes a beat-up looking, late-model Niss Sentra going in the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re CLOSE ON the radio as some Big Hair, Corporate Rock song like “DUST IN THE WIND” is playing. And we’ll WIDEN see that Julie is driving the car with Bryson sitting nex her. He notices how preoccupied she is.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: How come you’re not singing?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: Usually I have to stick my head out the window to drown out your voice when this song is playing. Julie looks at him for a long moment, hesitating.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s wrong, Mom? You have to tell me. You were the one who made up the “no secrets rule” after Dad left. Not me.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: (sighs, then) You’re right, Bry. Look, I don’t want you to worry about this, but the HMO is cutting back my hours. But I already have some ideas for how to make some more money.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: (without missing a beat) Yeah, it’s called basic math. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you make less, you have to spend less. I’m gonna drop out of swim club. It’s too expensive.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Whoa, we are not even going there, you understand me? I’1l eat Cup 0’ Noodles three times a day before you miss one minute of swim club. Bryson tries not to let on that he’s relieved by this -- it’s clear that he is. Something hopeful hits him.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: Maybe Dad will come through with his child support. Julie almost goes with skepticism, but thinks better of i

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Maybe he will. Which seems to lift his spirits.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: Cup O’ Noodles are pasta, right?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Loosely.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: Good. Coach Spinello says I need to start carbo-loading before meets. Julie smiles at his pluck. She loves this boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bedroom decorated out of the Pottery Barn catalog. Dave enters quietly, and sees that Clarice is already in bed w her back turned toward his side. He quietly slips out of sweats and climbs into bed, cuddling up against her.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You awake, baby? He kisses her shoulder, trying to arouse her.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got a big thing for you, baby, and it gettin’ bigger by the moment. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She turns further away from him. His face falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see that she is indeed awake, but in no mood to cooper And we'll HEAR the CRACK of a ball coming off a bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE’RE CLOSE ON A BASEBALL as it is grounded hard across t dirt toward a handsome, honey-toned kid, maybe 12, who is playing second base on a rundown inner-city field more di than grass. The boy, CARLOS, gets into position to scoop up, but the ball has eyes and squirts between his legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “Coach” Dave is holding the bat, and his assistant, Brock shagging the balls at home plate, and it’s clear that we in the middle of a Little League team practice. The team a Fat Albert gang of various shapes and sizes, some ragge some street-heartened. Besides Carlos, we’1ll come to kno few of them as JAYLEN, DARIUS, MARCUS and DESHAWN. Dave calls out to Carlos, slightly annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Carlos! How many times I got to tell you, son? Keep your hind end down. You gonna catch the ball on your chin if you pokin’ at it like it’s a bug! Which causes a round of SNICKERS from around the infield. Dave hits a pop fly which shortstop Deshawn has to race b to catch. When he snags it cleanly, he begins strutting around, show-boating.

dialogues.speaker: DESHAWN
dialogues.text: Who’s your daddy now, suckers?

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: Please, Baby A-Rod, stop actin’ like you meant to catch that ball. You luckier than a crackhead with a five-dollar scratcher. More HOOTS, HOWLS and AD LIB trash talk from the other bo Dave and Brock trade a weary look.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: All right, bring it in! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some boys sprint in and gather around Dave and Brock, oth drag in huffing and puffing. All are jabbering.

dialogues.speaker: JAYLEN
dialogues.text: Say, coach, when can I show you my curve ball?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: When you’re eighteen.

dialogues.speaker: JAYLEN
dialogues.text: Why I got to wait that long?

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: ‘Cause that’s when you’ll be an adult and your mama can’t sue us for you blowin’ out your arm. Generating some SNICKERS from some of the other boys.

dialogues.speaker: DESHAWN
dialogues.text: Coach Cracker snapped your ass!

dialogues.speaker: JAYLEN
dialogues.text: Shut up, fool! Brock gives Dave a “let it go” look. But it ain’t happeni

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Deshawn, are you feelin’ sick?

dialogues.speaker: DESHAWN
dialogues.text: No, coach.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Well, you must be sick because you got diarrhea of the mouth, boy. Now Deshawn gets his dose of derisive CHUCKLES.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (putting arm around Brock) I want to tell you all something. Coach Houseman here is my main man. He’s saved my butt more times than I want to admit, and if I had to go to war, he’s the only man in the world I would trust to get my back. (beat, then) Deshawn, what race am I? Deshawn looks a little confused. Like it’s a trick questi (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DESHAWN
dialogues.text: Black?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Wrong. I’m human first, then I’m black. There’s only one race of people, little brothers. The human race, and there are two kinds of people. Good ones and bad ones. (a beat, to Deshawn) So, D, what race is Coach Houseman?

dialogues.speaker: DESHAWN
dialogues.text: (happily thinks he has it) White! Brock throws Dave a smile. Dave gives a sigh.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: We'll have to work on that later. (blows his whistle) All right. Wind sprints. Which causes GROANS of protest from all over, especially plump Marcus, a pear-shaped boy with a tiny, tiny head.

dialogues.speaker: DARIUS
dialogues.text: Marcus can’t run. He too fat.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I ain’t fat. My mama say I just got big bones!

dialogues.speaker: DARIUS
dialogues.text: Boy, yo butt so fat if you farted it would take ‘til next week to come out! Huge LAUGHTER and lots of “skin” is slapped among the boy

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I like that, Darius. You been playin’ the dozens, haven't you?

dialogues.speaker: DARIUS
dialogues.text: Yeah, Coach. I keep it tight.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Well, guess what? You so pretty, if anybody beats you on one of these sprints, I’m gonna make you wear a dress in Saturday’s game. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dave blows his WHISTLE and the other boys take off runnin Darius’ cocky smile melts and he turns and joins the race Brock turns to Brock and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Damn, you're good. Way better than my little league coach. He used to check our cups before every game. Your coach ever do that?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: What do you mean “check?”

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: You know, stick his hand down there, move it around a little, make sure it everything was good.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (long askance look) No wonder you so messed up. Brock laughs at him. He got him again. But suddenly Dave' demeanor darkens. Brock sees that Dave is looking off in distance and follows his eyes to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darnell is approaching with a couple of what, in the inne city city, could be described as a “ho’s” in painted on j on his arm. He is chugging from a forty-ounce malt liquor and staring at us with red, dead eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Dave stares back, anger brewing in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: What’s Darnell doin’ here?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Come to watch Carlos play ball, I s'pose. Sparking a look of surprise from Brock as Darnell walks u

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ya'll not welcome here with that King Cobra, brother.

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: Shut up, bitch! I can come up in this piece and see my boy anytime I want. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Not drunk on your ass, you can’t. It's a bad influence on the boys. And it’s against league rules. (eyeing the “ho’s”) Now get outta here with your wannabe mack daddy entourage, or I’‘1l make it so you never see your boy play ball. If looks could kill, Dave would be a dead man. Darnell ha on him for a long moment, then throws up his hands.

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: Fuck it. Whatever. One of Darnell’s ladies snaps her thong at Dave as if to “don’t you wish,” then Darnell crosses off with them.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: You never told me he was Carlos’ father.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: He’s his daddy. But that’s a long way from bein’ his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re CLOSE ON A LADY’S SHOE rocking up and down. It’s a nice, dress shoe. Something an older woman might wear to church. And we'll WIDEN to see Mama, sitting on the sofa, dressed to the nines, her arms and legs crossed impatient She’s a decade older, but she hasn’t lost any of her spit Clarice enters from the hallway leading to the master bedroom, adjusting her earrings. She looks stunning, dres in the kind of gown you don to win an award. She looks at her watch, then goes to the window and looks out.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Where is Dave? He knew we had to leave by five-thirty.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: Honestly, girl, you need to keep a shorter leash on that man. Clarice ignores this, tries to change the subject. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: How do you like my new dress, Mama? Clarice has a little too much décolletage showing for Mam taste. She crosses over and pinches her lapels together.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: Lord have mercy, girl, are you tryin’ to give the players a free show? We need a safety pin. This thing ain’t got buttons where a Christian girl need buttons. Clarice brushes Mama’s hand away, slightly annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Mama, would you stop? At that moment, the front door opens and Dave walks in, h from practice, looking all sweaty in his coaching clothes

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Hey, baby, I’m home. What do you say we go grab a bite to -- He freezes when he sees them both. He’s clearly forgotten something. What that is suddenly dawns on him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m just gonna need me a minute. Without waiting for the shoe to drop, he hustles down the hallway and into the bedroom. Mama gives an exasperated s

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: That man is steppin’ on my last nerve.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. CLARICE’S CADILLAC - TRAVELING - NIGHT - MOMENTS LAT Dave is now in his nicest suit and putting pedal to the m as a frosty Clarice sits next to him while Mama stews in back. They come to a stop. An ambulance, lights and SIREN BLARING, flies through the intersection in front of them, headed to some emergency. But they don’t seem to notice. Dave tries to win back some brownie points as the light t green. He gives her dress the once-over. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Damn, Boo, are you ready for the red carpet or what? And Mama Clark, may I say, you are looking like a fine Nubian Queen tonight. Clarice and Mama's expressions don’t change.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: David, you knew how important this night was for me. Do you realize what an honor it is be the Salesperson of the Year?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I know, baby. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: And now we’re gonna be lucky if I make my entrance before they start servin’ the little egg rolls.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean to forget. I just got caught up with practice. Mama decides to break her silence.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: What I know, young man, is you got a priority problem. You need a priority transplant. Why you wastin’ your time with all those little gangsters with their drawers hangin’ all out? All they are is a bunch of thieves training to be crackheads like their daddies. (beat, then) Ask me, the only reason a black man ever gets out the ghetto is because a strong woman is there to keep his ho-mongerin’ butt in line.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: All due respect, Mama... not all men are like your ex-husband. Which sends a chill through the car. She glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: Maybe not all. But without your granny and my daughter ridin’ herd, you sure woulda been. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dave is bristling. Knows what he’d like to say, but can’t Clarice decides to offer an olive branch. Sort of.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: All I know is, if you put in as much time on your business as you do with those boys... (she touches his arm) ++. you might be able to get out of the dungarees and look this fine every day. As Dave drives them through the next intersection, he tur to accept her peace offering -- DAVE’S POV - OVER CLARICE From out of nowhere, a PICK UP TRUCK is barreling toward passenger side of their car.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: The truck SLAMS into the Cadillac at full speed in a sickening impact which feels like a nuclear shock-wave. INT. CLARICE’S CADILLAC - NIGHT - CONTINUOUS And inside, it’s instantly all grinding metal and flying glass and everything goes into SURREAL SLOW-MOTION as Dav sees the truck cave in Clarice’s side of the car, and everything begins spinning as Dave and Clarice’s heads bounce into deployed air bags. And things keep spinning f a few more revolutions until the car suddenly jolts to a and we return to REAL TIME. Dave looks over at Clarice and we PUSH IN on him. Everyth FADES TO BLACK and goes DEATHLY SILENT and stays that way what seems like an eternity until we begin making out a frail, moaning, weeping voice.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh, Sweet Jesus. Oh, Sweet Jesus. Lord have mercy. Suddenly, we FADE BACK UP as Dave comes back to conscious and realizes what has just happened. Mama is in the back seat, holding her head in her hands and still moaning aft Jesus. He looks over at Clarice who is unconscious.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Reesie, talk to me. You okay, baby? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: No response. He checks her pulse, and listens to her ches

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's good, you breathin’ strong. You keep breathin’, baby. Dave puts his hand on Mama’s shoulder. She shaking. Weak.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You all right, Mama?

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I got to get us some help. Dave tries to open his door. It’s jammed. He puts his shoulder into it. This time it opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave staggers out of the car, a little woosy, and moves around to the other side. He’s got glass cuts all over hi face and a nasty bump emerging on his forehead. In the b. other cars are stopping and ONLOOKERS are rushing over.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (yelling out) Please, somebody call 9-1-1! Somebody get us some help. A MALE ONLOOKER crosses over, just hanging up his cell ph

dialogues.speaker: MALE ONLOOKER
dialogues.text: It’s okay, guy. Help’s on the way.

dialogues.speaker: PICK UP TRUCK
dialogues.text: A ratty-looking TEENAGER, who has so many facial piercing looks like he fell into a fishing tackle box, emerges fro smoking truck that has fared even worse than the Cadillac has bumps and scratches, but appears not to be too badly hurt. He is dazed and confused as he paces back and forth

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGER
dialogues.text: I didn’t see the red. I’m sorry. I’m sorry. I was just reaching for my cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now, other onlookers have made their way to the car. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: My wife’s pinned in, and my mother- in-law’s still in the back. The first onlooker manages to yank open Mama’s back door.

dialogues.speaker: MALE ONLOOKER
dialogues.text: Let me help you out, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: (panicky) No, just get my Reesie out. Dave comes over to comfort her.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Mama, we gonna get her out. This man gonna let you lie down in his car until our ambulance comes. The man gives Dave a nod that says “absolutely.” Reluctan Mama lets the man help her climb out of the car and escor her slowly over to his car. One of the other onlookers sp something on the ground he doesn’t like.

dialogues.speaker: MALE ONLOOKER
dialogues.text: You got fuel leaking. Dave looks at the leaking fuel. His face fills with dread INT. CLARICE’S CADILLAC - NIGHT - SECONDS LATER Dave slides back in the front seat next to Clarice. She i still out cold. Dave looks and sees how wickedly pinned h leg is by the twisted metal. He gently pats her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Clarice, baby, can you hear me? Boo, I need you to wake up. After a few beats, her eyes flit open and she suddenly realizes what’s going on. She looks at her leg and her ey and voice fill with tears and panic.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Jesus, my side hurts so bad. And my leg... I can’t feel my leg!

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I know, baby. We gonna get you out of here real soon. She claws at the door, but it’s useless. She begins sobbi (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I’m so scared, David! I don’t wanna die! I don’t wanna die! Dave gets as good an angle on a hug as he can to comfort

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Shhh, baby, I ain’t gonna let nothin’ else happen to you. On the sound of HYDRAULICS and CRUNCHING STEEL --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON the JAWS OF LIFE cutting through steel. WIDEN to two FIREMEN working the rig as Dave stands by. In the b.g an ambulance, firetruck and police cars are now on the sc

dialogues.speaker: FIREMAN
dialogues.text: Almost there, Ma’am. Hang on just a little longer. A beat later, the passenger door falls to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice is now on a gurney, her leg and neck immobilized. The paramedics slide the gurney into the back of an ambulance. Mama is already there with a LADY EMT.

dialogues.speaker: PARAMEDIC
dialogues.text: (into shoulder radio) Thirty-six-year-old African- American female with obvious leg fractures and possible concussion. BP ninety-five over sixty. As Dave climbs in, he looks at Mama and finds there is no love in her eyes. The paramedics slam the doors shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUBLE DOORS slam open with the force of Clarice’s gurney TRAUMA NURSES and DOCTORS receive it from the paramedics. Dave and Mama try to follow them, but a nurse stops them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I got to go in there with her! She needs me!

dialogues.speaker: TRAUMA NURSE
dialogues.text: We'll take good care of her, sir. She notices that Mama is looking very fatigued and examin nasty gash on the side of Dave’s head.

dialogues.speaker: TRAUMA NURSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Besides, you all could use a little TLC yourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're facing two emergency room beds, partitioned by a curtain. On one side, Dave is sitting with his shirt off, getting his head wound stitched up by an E.R. DOCTOR. Dav is clearly worried. Next door, Mama is reclining in the b wearing a hospital gown and a heart monitor. ANGLE ON DAVE’S BED

dialogues.speaker: E.R. DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (as he works on Dave) How you doin’ over there, Mrs. Clark? From the other side of the curtain comes the reply.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I told that other doctor -- some Filipino or Chinese or some damn thing -- I do not need these wires hangin’ all up offa me. I just need to be with my baby girl. The Doctor trades a knowing look with Dave.

dialogues.speaker: E.R. DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Just a precaution, ma’am. We just need to monitor your heart a while longer. Just then one of the Trauma Doctors we saw earlier enters crosses to Dave’s bed. He’s wearing surgical scrubs and a serious expression. He relieves the E.R. Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: TRAUMA DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Give me a moment, Gerald. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The E.R. Doctor takes his cue and crosses off.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (quickly alarmed) What is it, Doc? What’s happenin’ with Clarice?

dialogues.speaker: TRAUMA DOCTOR
dialogues.text: We've got her stabilized, Mr. Johnson, but we've got a long night ahead of us The curtain partition between the beds immediately draws and Mama is staring at them intently.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: It's already been a long night. What else you go to say?

dialogues.speaker: TRAUMA DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Her leg is badly fractured. But what has me more concerned at the moment is that she ruptured her spleen, which means she’s bleeding internally. As bad as the leg is, we've got to get in there and stop that bleeding first.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: Oh, dear Jesus, we need you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (emotion welling up) I don’t care what it takes, or what it costs, you’ve got to fix her, Doc. You got to fix her. The Doctor gives him an understanding nod and exits. Dave and Mama sit in silence for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: If we wasn’t in such a hurry, maybe this wouldn’t have happened. Mama lays back on her bed. Dave doesn’t reply. He can’t.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave, his head bandaged, his face weary, hovers over Clarice’s bed in the wee hours of the morning. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Clarice is in a post-op anesthetic twilight, her leg is elevated in a cast and in traction. Behind Dave, Mama is SNORING softly in a recliner, as the Trauma Doctor enters checks the charts.

dialogues.speaker: TRAUMA DOCTOR
dialogues.text: You got one tough cookie here, Mr. Johnson. Before she went under, she kept telling me I was not allowed to remove any of her body parts without her permission.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (smiling) That’s my Reesie.

dialogues.speaker: TRAUMA DOCTOR
dialogues.text: The tear in the spleen was small enough to patch. It should heal up in a week or so. But the leg’s another matter.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: How bad is it?

dialogues.speaker: TRAUMA DOCTOR
dialogues.text: We had to put pins in three places. She’s not going to be able to bear weight on it for a good a month.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: She won’t be happy to hear that. She’s gonna wanna get back to work the moment she gets out of here.

dialogues.speaker: TRAUMA DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnson, this is a very severe injury. If she doesn’t want to have to park in the handicapped spot the rest of her life, she is going to need months of rehabilitation. You need to make her understand that. Dave sighs, not looking forward to that assignment.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Maybe you could give me some of them drugs you used to keep her knocked out. The Trauma Doctor smiles and exits the room. Dave looks o at Mama. Still catching sawing logs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He leans over Clarice, gently brushes her hair with his fingers and whispers encouragement to her even though he knows she can’t hear him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I love you, Boo. Somehow we gonna get through this. As he kisses her on her forehead, PUSH IN on her closed e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THOSE SAME EYES. They slowly open, red, disoriented as she gets her bearings. And WIDEN to see that Dave has not left her side. His heart skips to see her coming to.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Good morning, beautiful. Clarice’s concern grows when she sees her leg in traction

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: (weakly, tearing up) Oh, David. What did they do to my poor leg?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Shhh, baby. You may not be able to go through any metal detectors for awhile, but we gonna get you back in them short skirts real soon.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: How soon?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Soon enough. Clarice looks around the room, suddenly panicky.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Oh, dear God, where’s Mama? Please tell me she didn’t --

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: She's fine, Reesie. Crotchety as hell. I made her take a cab home to get some sleep ‘cause the nurses were about to run her out of here on a rail. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Clarice smiles a little. At that moment, the world’s larg Teddy Bear enters the room, manhandled there by Brock.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Good Lord, that better not be for me.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: You kidding? (points at Dave) This is for my boy over here. Brock thrusts the Teddy Bear at Dave.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: This is what I brought for you. He pulls a flower arrangement from behind his back and ha it to her. She smells the flowers and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They’re gorgeous, B. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: So are you, sweetie. Brock gives her a kiss on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (mock flirting) Especially in that sexy hospital gown.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Please. You gonna set off my blood pressure. Dave smiles. These are some special friendships.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave and Brock. A walk and talk. Dave’s looking reflectiv

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: I’m sorry this happened to you, bro. Really makes you count your blessings.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Yeah. How you always just a blink away from losing them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They ponder this for a beat. Don’t want to dig much deepe

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, Coach Cracker, how you feel about takin’ over the team for awhile? Think you can handle those little thugs all by yourself?

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Hell yes. When they find out I’m really the brains of the operation, they’1l be eating out of my hand. (beat) Plus, I’m gonna bring some Popeye's for game snack. Dave chuckles. That ought to do the trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good-looking account executive in his late-30s, TED SAW is busy drawing in a sketch pad. He’s deep in creative mo because there are several sketches for some ad campaign t all over the walls. The door opens and an attractive, you secretary with legs for miles, KATE, pops her head in.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Ted, you have a visitor. I tried to tell her you’re on a deadline --

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (not looking up) Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (with attitude) The ex-Mrs. Ted Sawyer. Julie pushes past Kate into Ted’s office. She’s in her P. work clothes -- dowdy compared to a fashion plate like Ka

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I didn’t think the future ex-Mrs. Sawyer would mind me barging in.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t know what you mean. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kate looks Kate flips He glares checkbook 45.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Both of you working on a weekend? Trust me, Bambi, you’re not the first secretary Ted’s bumped uglies with in the copy room. at Ted, aghast. He gives her a reassuring nod.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Give us a minute, Kate. her hair indignantly and exits. Ted eyes Julie.

dialogues.speaker: TED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know I’m supposed to ask to what I owe the pleasure... but I don’t feel like pretending.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Me either. Only reason I’m here is because the HMO cut back my hours.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: That’s a shame. Maybe you should to get a better job.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Maybe you should grow some cajones and stop being a deadbeat dad. I could care less that you don’t feel any obligation to the mother of your child. But the three-thousand dollars in back child support you owe your son makes me want to break your kneecaps -- and believe me, I know how to do it.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: You know I just started with this firm a few months ago and that I was in between jobs for awhile.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Stop banging every skirt you see and you won’t get fired so often. at her for a long beat. He then retrieves a from his desk drawer and begins to write a check.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I can only afford two-hundred right now. I’1ll try to send some more in a few weeks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: (takes check from him) I'd say “thanks” but that’s usually reserved for somebody who does something for you without having their arm twisted. She goes to the door and turns back.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, Bryson is really coming along with his swimming. In fact, he has his first meet later today. (beat, then) It might be nice if he knew his dad gave a damn. Guilt fills Ted’s eyes. Julie opens the door to find an insecure, nosy Kate standing there, eavesdropping. Julie gives her a condescending smile and then exits past her.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. ALL SAINTS HOSPITAL —- PRIVATE ROOM - DAY Clarice’s room is now filled with flowers and Get Well gi Dave examines a card from one of the arrangements.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: This one’s from Michelle. (reading) “Roses are red, violets are blue... Girl, we holdin’ your big ass real estate trophy so you better get well soon.” But it’s a reminder of her loss and the reality of her situation. She looks away, tears filling her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t cry, Reesie. We gonna get through this.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: (flashing on him) We ain’t the one with the leg twisted up like a damn pretzel.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You're right, baby. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Why did this have to happen? Everything was swimmin’ along so perfectly. It was gonna be my big night, standin’ up there, gettin’ that award, showin’ the world that I’ve arrived. That I am somebody.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Baby, don’t do that. You been a somebody to me since the first day I met you. You’re my somebody. She looks at Dave, thinking about that, and holds back fr saying what she really wants to say. It’s not lost on Dav A KNOCK at the door interrupts the moment. They turn to s winsome black woman in her 40s, CARMEN MCATEE, wearing a colorful African kaftan and her hair in dreads. She’s a b woman, but all the equipment’s in the right proportions.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Dave and Clarice? I’m Carmen McAtee, from the counseling center up at Emmanuel Fellowship. Clarice wipes her eyes, throws on a smile as Carmen enter

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Excuse my face. I never got to put on my war paint today. They all shake hands and AD LIB greetings.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Bishop Wilkes asked me to come pay you a visit. Dave and Clarice trade looks.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Really? Wasn’t that sweet of him. I’m surprised he heard about the accident so soon.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Well, your mama was bendin’ his ear all morning’ about it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: We haven’t really been comin’ to church lately. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, she told him that, too. Awkward moment for Dave and Clarice. Not for Carmen.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How is that leg feeling? Looks like one big item for the prayer chain right there.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Thanks, but I’m sure there are other people in the church in more dire prayer need than me.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Well, we did have one young brother from the gospel choir stick a communion cup up his nose trying to impress his girl, but I think this leg is still takin’ home first prize this week. Clarice can’t hold back a smile over that image. However.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Please thank the Bishop for his concern, but we're fine... really. You must have other people you need to visit.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Nope. Just you. To Clarice’s surprise, Carmen pulls up a chair and smiles

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why don’t we read some scripture. Do you have a favorite passage? As Carmen pulls out a bible, Dave and Clarice exchange flabbergasted looks.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m feelin’ a little drowsy. As long as we can stay away from all the begets and begats.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: And anything dealin’ with locusts and pillars of salt and shit... (catching himself) Excuse me, Lord. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Carmen gives them a smile that says “sure.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An encased, elevated leg is the first thing through the automatic doors. A black LADY NURSE with a pushy, “talk t the hand” attitude is guiding Clarice out into the sunshi in her wheelchair. Mama and Dave follow not far behind, D loaded to the hilt with flowers and presents.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: I hope you rented a decent car, David.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I brought my work van.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: Work van? Boy, are you outta your mind? We can’t put this girl up in some nasty old janitor van. What she gonna do, sit in a mop bucket?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Mama, it’s okay. It’s got a back seat I can lay down in.

dialogues.speaker: PUSHY NURSE
dialogues.text: I don’t care what car ya’ll brought up in here as long as you pulled it up to the drive. Dave gets a busted look on his face and his non-response speaks volumes.

dialogues.speaker: PUSHY NURSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, hell no. Don’t tell me ya’ll forgot to pull it up to the drive.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Sorry. I didn’t know I was supposed to.

dialogues.speaker: PUSHY NURSE
dialogues.text: Son, what do you think this is, Disneyland? This ain’t no tram ride. If you think I’m gonna push this damn chair all over this parking lot, you need to be in the looney wing with a lithium drip. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Humiliating beat for Dave, then:

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I’m just gonna need me a minute. Dave hustles past them, struggling to juggle all the Get loot in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave's butt making that back-and-forth power-walker motio

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The Nurse is enjoying the view.

dialogues.speaker: PUSHY NURSE
dialogues.text: (salaciously) Hmm-mmm. Look at that tight little ass. I'd like to bounce a silver dollar offa that ass and make me change for the vending machine. OFF Clarice and Mama’s looks of shock and awe --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave pushes Clarice’s wheelchair into their bedroom. They are home. Clarice takes in the place with a sigh.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Home, sweet, prison.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Come on, baby. We gonna make it real nice for you.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Well, if I’m gonna be trapped up in here for the next several weeks, there are going to be some changes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: What changes?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: No offense, but this just ain’t your forte. Get my cellphone. I need a sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice is sitting in bed in a silk robe with her leg up. She has her face on and an eager look in her eyes. A litt desk has been set up next to the bed. Dave shows Michelle into the room. She’s carrying a file box. As soon as she and Clarice see each other, they do this girlfriend SQUEA and Michelle rushes over to her. Clarice holds out her ha

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Fly me some fingers, girl. Michelle and Clarice happily go through the routine of wiggling their fingers together. Clarice notices Dave watching them, amused, from the door.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please, if you and your crew be bumpin’ butts together, we can fly some fingers.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I like it. Looks kind of nasty though -- in a good way. Clarice waves him off and looks at Michelle.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: You sure you don’t mind working out of the “home office” for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: You kidding? Kickin’ it with my home-girl? It’ll be like we havin’ a get-rich slumber party. (remembering something) I almost forgot. She opens the box and pulls out a beautiful crystal troph shaped like a triangle and hands it to Clarice.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To the Salesperson of the Year. It takes Clarice’s breath away. She almost tears up as sh runs her fingers across the inscription.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I have died and gone to heaven. Dave is happy for his wife. And hopeful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re CLOSE ON Clarice. She has turned away the world and her demeanor is dark, frustrated, angry. WIDEN to discove discouraged-looking Michelle, holding her file box, stand at the door with a grim Dave.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Who was I kidding? I can’t sell no damn real estate from a bed. The Reids laughed me off the phone when I asked them if they’d mind comin’ here to write an offer sheet.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: Forget about them. They just uppity ass black folk who think they shit smell like perfume. I bet Monday gonna go a whole lot smoother.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: There isn’t gonna be any Monday. Thanks for givin’ this a try, Michelle, but just tell everybody at Hastings I’m outta the game.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: You are not out the game, girl. Mr. Hastings says you take all the time you need. And if you need more time after that, we’ll cross that bridge when we come to it.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Or jump off it. Dave gives Michelle look indicating that she should go.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: Okay, I’m outta here, but I’m gonna be blowin’ up your cell real soon. Clarice doesn’t respond. Dave and Michell trade another l and she exits sadly down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Boo, can I get you any --

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: You go, too. (off his hurt look) (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t wanna see or talk to anybody right now. Not even you. An unnerving thing for him to hear. And PRELAP a DOORBELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave opens the front door and Mama is there, suitcases in hand, looking very ill-tempered.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
