dialogues.text: Why I had to hear about my Reesie’s heart breaking from her rather than from the man s’posed to protect her makes me want to slap somebody. She drops her two suitcases at Dave’s feet.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can put those in the guest room.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Look, Mama, I appreciate your concern, but we been married twelve years. I think I can take care of my own wife. Clarice had a rough day, but we gonna get by just fine. Mama gives a little sarcastic snort.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: Let me break it down for you. If things was all jiggy as that, then I wouldn’t be here, would I? Now move your butt and let me take care of my daughter. The look in her eye makes Dave a little afraid. He steps aside and lets her by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brock enters the gym and passes the group of players we m earlier. Apparently they are done working out.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Hey rookies, where ya'll going? Who wants some dribbling lessons? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Big Dude just shakes his head and points down court.

dialogues.speaker: BIG SMILING DUDE
dialogues.text: We tried to get our game on, but somebody hoggin’ up half the court. Brock turns and is surprised to see Dave shooting hoops a by himself at the other end of the gym. And given his swe factor and fatigued look, he’s been here awhile.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: He slam dunks the ball and the whole backboard shudders. he turns back the court, a basketball is fired at him fro o.s. and he catches it, surprised. We ADJUST to see Brock

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Dude, either Clarice is making the world’s fastest recovery... or you got your walkin’ papers.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (glowering) Don’t ask.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Mama? Dave answers by firing the ball back at Brock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A race is under way in the b.g. and the stands are full o CHEERING parents.

dialogues.speaker: WARM UP AREA
dialogues.text: Julie is organizing Bryson’s warm-up bag as Bryson does s stretching nearby. She sees that he keeps looking over hi shoulder at the stadium entrance. It makes her sad for hi

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Hey, did you get a look at that other team’s warm up sweats? Yellow and chartreuse. I’m having a very gruesome flashback of a college pizza and beer party. The little attempt at humor doesn’t really register with (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: You think Dad’s gonna make it? I emailed him and left a message on his voicemail.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: (sighing) I don’t know, Bry. Bryson covers his true feelings with a brave smile.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: No big deal. He probably has to work. I bet he’1ll come next week.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (OVER P.A.)
dialogues.text: First call. Two-hundred Individual Medly

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: (as he yanks off warm ups) That’s me. I’m going to go hurl in the bathroom first. Then I’1l see you at the finish line. Bryson crosses off. Julie watches him go for a long momen This kid is so brave and full of so much life. Just then, her cell phone RINGS. She looks at the caller ID, answers

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Hey, Boss, what’s up? (beat, then brightening) Are you kidding? I’m all over it. She finds a pen in her pocket and finds an empty soda cup

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, go ahead. (writing on cup) You're a life-saver, Nick. Remind me to give you a quickie on Monday. (oh shit) Yes, actually that was a joke. She hangs up, and gives a little victory pump of her fist

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: INT. JULIE’S NISSAN - TRAVELING - DAY Julie is driving slowly through the same neighborhood we Brock driving his Beamer in earlier. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: (checking out houses) Okay, Julie, welcome to Stepford. A white Hummer being driven by a blond lady yuppie comes whipping around a corner and Julie has to take evasive ac to avoid it. The lady gives Julie a look that says “what you doing in this neighborhood?” Which pisses Julie off.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (derisively) Nice tank, Barbie. Where do your kids play soccer - Iraq? And we PRELAP one of those annoying KNOCKS at your door ( quick knocks followed by two long ones).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama comes the door and answers it. Julie is standing the with her bag of P.T. gear and a friendly smile. Mama give her the once-over.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: Go away. We ain’t buyin’ nothin.’ Julie looks a little confused. Dave now comes to the door

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: It's okay, Mama. I got it. (to Julie) Can I help you? Julie looks at a little sheet of paper.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I hope I have the right address. I’m Julie Sawyer. You called for an in-home physical therapist. Dave looks at her, now getting it. Mama throws up her han and grouses as she retreats within the house.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Physical therapist? Little bitty thing like you? What do ya’ll work on -- hamsters?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Sorry about that. I’m Dave Johnson. Please come in. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Julie crosses in with her gear.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I actually did work on a hamster once. In school. Wrung the poor little thing’s neck. Now I’m only allowed to work on humans. Dave doesn’t know whether to laugh -- until Julie gives h wry smile -- which gives him permission to chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama enters the room first, followed by Dave and Julie. W Clarice sees her, she does not try to cover her downcast demeanor like we’ve seen her do before.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Reesie, this is Julie Sawyer. She’s the physical therapist we asked the hospital to send over.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I didn’t ask them. You did. Julie gives Dave a reassuring look. Mama is watching her like a hawk from the corner of the room. Already doesn’t like what she sees. Julie sets down her gear and pulls up chair next to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Clarice, after what you’ve been through, I know the last thing you want is some stranger in your life. So let’s just start by talking. Clarice turns and eyes her knowingly.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I ain’t looking for anyone to psychoanalyze me either.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Good. Because I’m not looking to get sued for masquerading as a psychologist either. Clarice’s affectation remains flat and Mama remains skeptical. But Dave has to smile a little on that one. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But talking about how you’re feeling emotionally can help me design a better plan for getting you back up on that leg again. Clarice’s eyes fill with tears of frustration.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: You’re asking how I feel? I feel like damn Humpty-Dumpty sittin’ in a million pieces at the bottom of the wall. In the last two weeks, my life has gone from top of the world to complete shit! That’s how I feel! Mama’s not biting her tongue anymore. She lasers in on Ju

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: Okay, Miss Sunshine, that is about all of this nonsense I’m gonna put up with. Can’t you see you makin’ things worse? Time to scoot that perky little behind outta here. But intervention comes from a surprising source.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: No, Mama. It ain’t her fault. She’s just doing her job. (to Dave, Mama) Give us some time alone. Please. Mama starts to say something, but thinks better of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie has her gear bag in hand and Dave is escorting her

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I’m worried about her. I’ve never seen her so...

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Depressed? Dave nods sadly as they come to the front door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A little depression is normal in these cases. She’s been through a very traumatic experience. Soon as she sees she’s making progress, she'll snap out of it. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Thanks for being gentle with her.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: You’re a good husband to want her treated gently, Mr. Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Please call me Dave, Mrs. Sawyer, It doesn’t make me feel so old.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: In that case, it’s Miss Sawyer. (smiles, offers hand) And I’m Julie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave smiles and reciprocates with a warm handshake. Julie then exits out the front door. But someone is watching.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Watching from a rocking chair is Mama. And as begin HEARI a tune like Luther Vandross’ “HERE AND NOW,” we can see t Mama didn’t like that exchange one little bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another visit by Julie, and this time, she has Clarice working with hand weights, making rowing motions with her arms... keeping her from upper body atrophy. B) And yet another session with Clarice -- this time rais and lowering her non-injured leg. Hip work. And we begin HEARING Dave’s remembering voice again.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Something’s always confused me about the story of Adam and Eve. God made man first and gave hima whole bunch of instructions. Work, cultivate, protect. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But God never gave Eve any instructions. Not one. It all fell on Adam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave returns to his team and his boys greet him happily, crowding around him, giving him “Bash Brother” high-fives including one from Brock. D) Darnell watching the whole scene from inside his beat old Hooptie (station wagon) parked on the street next to field. He takes a drag from a joint, and drives on a park

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And ever since then, a man has been defined by the roles he performed. By how good he worked and cultivated. By how good he protected his wife and children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Dave is transferring Clarice from her wheelchair into their bed, he tries to give her a peck on the cheek, but she’s in a testy mood and wants no part of it. F) INT. BROCK HOUSEMAN’S DOWNTOWN CONDO - NIGHT Brock comes home from work to discover his phone blinking Messages.” He sighs and pushes the “Delete All” button.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The world has always wanted men to be heroes. But somewhere that all changed. I’m not sayin’ all the changes were bad. Lord knows, inequality no matter what kind, needs to stay dead and buried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice is sitting in her wheelchair on the front porch, reading her “House Beautiful” magazine when Dave pulls up her beautifully repaired Cadillac. Good as new. H) INT. ALL SAINTS HOSPITAL - DOCTOR’S OFFICE - DAY Dave holds Clarice’s hand as the Trauma Doctor we remembe from earlier cuts off her cast and removes the exterior r Clarice grimaces when she sees her wicked scars and how withered her leg has gotten. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Women started bein’ their own heroes. Maybe because their men forgot how to be, or maybe because they didn’t want to be protected anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the swim stadium, Bryson wins yet another race and his swim club teammates all do a congratulatory pile on him w he climbs out of the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie pays another P.T. visit. Now the real work begins. Slowly, painfully manipulating Clarice’s leg. Mama is hanging out nearby. Can’t bear to watch.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When Clarice and I first married, she treated me like I was her Zulu prince. And I wanted nothing more than to protect and cherish her. But when she started being the real bread-winner, that all began to change. K) And now Clarice is sitting on an exercise bike slowly pedaling. Then faster. Even faster. L) Clarice is in her wheelchair in the living room. As Da and Mama watch, Julie hands her a cane. At first Clarice doesn’t want to try it. But Julie gives her an encouragin “you can do it” smile. Finally, Clarice plants the cane i front of her and pulls herself up into a standing positio She can’t believe it. She’s up on her own two legs.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: See, when the world takes away a man’s reasons for bein’ a man -- when he loses his self-identity, purpose, passion and self-respect -- somehow things always go wrong. That’s one lesson my Granny never prepared me for. Then she takes a step and a breaks into a broad victory smile. Even Mama has to smile about this. And Dave gives Julie a look of thanks as the SONG and our MONTAGE ENDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave, carrying Julie’s gear, is walking out to her car.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Sometimes I never thought I'd see her back on her feet. I don’t know how to thank you, Julie.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Well, first you can send a “Happy Letter” to my boss, telling him you’ve never met a more skilled and professional physical therapist.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (smiling) Done. Julie opens her trunk and Dave stows her gear.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Second, Clarice needs several more weeks of therapy and I need the cash, so please don’t cut me off.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Wouldn’t think of it. Julie climbs into her car. Dave hovers at her door. Julie looks up at him and looks at him sincerely.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: You know, I’ve been doing this a long time. Most spouses bail by about the third session. You being so supportive of Clarice is more important to her progress than you realize.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Maybe you could write Mama one of them happy letters about me. She gets a giggle from this and looks at him appreciative

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Well, I gotta pick up my son. See ya, Monday. She goes to turn her key. A gruesome GRINDING NOISE comes from her engine. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shit! (catching herself) Sorry. My frigging battery is always doing this! She tries the ignition again. More GRINDING, then a horri CLUNKING NOISE. Dave raises his eyebrows.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I know a little about cars, and that ain’t no dead battery sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice and Mama are having some tea at the kitchen table when Dave enters and grabs some keys off the rack.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Julie's car’s dead. I’m gonna run her home.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: How come the girl can’t call a tow truck?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Because she’s gonna be late to pick up her boy.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: Maybe she shoulda thought of that before comin’ over here in that broke-ass car. Dave gives Clarice a look like “somebody's about to be hu

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Dave's right, Mama. We can’t make her late for her boy. Besides, this girl has been here for us, and we can return the favor. Dave gives Clarice a kiss on the cheek, which this time s receives, and heads for the door. Mama feels slighted.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: Ain’t my driveway gettin’ all oilly from some little made-in-China car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. CLARICE’S CADILLAC - TRAVELING - DAY The sun is sinking as Dave and Julie drive through downto

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I really appreciate this. I’ve never been late to pick Bryson up. I’m sure he doesn’t notice, but I’m trying to keep my record perfect. At that moment, they pass by a storefront business whose ALARM BELL is ringing. They don’t seem to notice. Dave is preoccupied with question he doesn’t quite know how to as

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Look, it ain’t none of my business, but how did you... I mean, what happened to --

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: How did I end up a single mother? Dave gives her an apologetic nod.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Believe me, I wish the story was more dramatic than it is. Like I’m widowed because my husband died on Flight 93 or something. Truth is, I’m just a middle-class cliche.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Ted and I -- that’s my ex-husband -- were the perfect little yuppie couple. We met at SMU, got married after graduation, got our careers started, saved up for a house, and then had Bryson. (beat, sighing) But then I found out Ted had this disease called “Ashley Syndrome.”

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Ashley Syndrome? What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: You get it from being attracted to twenty-two-year-old pole dancers named Ashley. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (suddenly getting it) Oh. Sorry. Didn’t mean to pry.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: It's okay. We’ve been divorced for two years. I used to chop up cucumbers every night and think of him. I’m down to once a week now. Which makes Dave chuckle. She enjoys it his laughter. Dav can feel her eyes on him. He points out the window.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Is this the swim club?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: (looking, nodding) Yeah. Pull in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cadillac pulls up to a confused-looking Bryson. INT. CLARICE’S CADILLAC - NIGHT - CONTINUOUS Julie rolls down her window for Bryson.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Hi, Bry. Bryson looks in warily. Sees a big black dude driving.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: Mom, please tell me this is about car trouble and we’re not being kidnapped or something... Dave bursts out laughing. Julie realizes how this looks.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Oh, God. No, Bryson, this is Dave Johnson. His wife is my patient. Remember? The ones in the accident.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. No offense, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (still chuckling) None taken, little man. You just watchin’ out for your mama. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: (to Bryson) I’m afraid it’s a little worse than the battery this time. Dave offered to give us a lift home.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: Cool. Bryson opens the back door and slides in. Bryson checks o the leather seats as Dave pulls back onto the boulevard.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dude, this is a nice ride.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Thanks. You shoulda seen it six weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: Mom, we need something like this instead of that crappy Sentra. Dave trades a smile with Julie.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: So your mom says you like King Kong up in that pool.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: Mom should stop talking so much.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: She thinks I’m gonna e like some Olympic gold medalists someday and I’‘1l get all this endorsement money and then she can mooch off me.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: It could happen.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: See, now I’m the wrong man to talk swimmin’. Only freestyle I know about is rappers spittin’ rhymes on a street corner. But you stick a basketball or a baseball in my hand I got the skills to pay the bills. Somehow this has touched a nerve in Bryson. Julie notices (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: I’ve only played baseball once. My dad took me to the park to play catch a couple years ago. Dave looks at Bryson in rear-view mirror. The kid is look out the window. Julie gives Dave a “sorry about that” loo

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Tell you what. I got this Little League team I coach. Any time your mom wants to bring you by, I can hook you up with a few pointers.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: (brightening) That would be totally ridiculous! Dave looks at him, a little confused.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: It means “cool.”

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: We practice over at Eastside Field. So you might... stand out a little, if you know what I’m sayin’.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: Guess I’1ll have to work on my tan. Dave gives Julie a smile. Smart kid. She should be proud.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. JULIE AND BRYSON’S BUNGLAOW - DAY - MOMENTS LATER The Cadillac pulls up to a clean, modest little house on lower middle-class street full of similar homes. As Bryso gets out with his swim bag, Julie follows Dave to the tru When he opens it, she quickly grabs her gear bag.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: See, now the way it works is, the man’s s’posed to carry the bags.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Except when the woman needs to show she isn’t totally pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I insist. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: After a long beat, she relents. Hands him the gear.

dialogues.speaker: ANGLE TO FRONT PORCH
dialogues.text: As they cross to the house, Bryson is already opening the front door. He calls back to Dave.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: See ya, Coach.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Keep it tight, Bryson. Bryson scampers inside as Dave and Julie get to the porch

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Soon as I get inside, I’ll call a tow, get my car out of your hair.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Look, I know a guy who runs a repair shop. Why don’t you let me get him to take a look.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: (suddenly concerned) That’s really sweet, but I can’t really afford a big repair bill --

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Trust me. This guy owes me. (offering his hand) And Clarice and I owe you. After a long beat, she shakes on it reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Thank you. I mean it. It's awkward for a beat. She leans in and gives hima grateful kiss on the cheek, then enters and closes her do Dave stands there for a moment feeling strangely exhilara

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON wheel blocks, and WIDEN to see Julie’s car has b pushed into Dave’s garage and is up on Jacks. Dave slides out from underneath on a dolly, holding on to some engine part. He’s got grease on his hands and face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. JULIE AND BRYSON’S BUNGLAOW - NIGHT - EVEN LATER With a little grease still on his face, Dave is at Julie’ front door. He places Julie’s car keys in a mailbox hangi near the door. And tucks a note in the screen door.

dialogues.speaker: ANGLE TO CAR
dialogues.text: Dave crosses back to the street where Brock’s Beamer is waiting with the engine running. As he does, we now see t Julie’s Sentra is parked in her driveway. INT. BROCK’'S BEAMER - NIGHT - CONTINUOUS Dave opens the door and slides in next to Brock who is dressed in what looks like pajamas and a tee-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: That must be one special physical therapist to interrupt my beauty sleep like this.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: She is.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: You think she’s seein’ anyone?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Just drive, fool. Brock shrugs it off with a smile and guns the accelerator EXT. JULIE AND BRYSON’S BUNGLAOW - NIGHT - CONTINUOUS The porch light comes on and the door opens. Julie finds note just as the Beamer is driving off. Confused, she ope the note and we read it with her over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Julie... I didn’t want to wake you. All you needed was a new solenoid, so I was able to fix it myself. Hope it won’t give you any trouble for awhile. Blessings... Dave. As she watches the Beamer disappear around a corner, Juli gives a stunned smile that just says “wow.” And we’ll HEA the sound of church BELLS RINGING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. EMMANUEL FELLOWSHIP CHURCH —- SANCTUARY - DAY The service has not yet begun, but the pews are filling u Bishop Wilkes -- looking a little older and wiser than wh we last saw him -- is down front greeting his parishioner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice looks stunning in her best church dress and hat a she slowly enters with the aid her cane. Dave, in his bes suit, is at her side. Mama, also looking lovely, follows behind, AD LIBBING greetings with acquaintances like a mo hen. Michelle, already there with her handsome husband TO stands up in her pew and gasps when she sees Clarice walk

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: Lord Jesus, I’m having a vision! She rushes over and embraces Clarice, and they both have work hard to hold back their tears.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Hi, sister girl.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: Look at you! Walkin’ like Black Miss America down the runway to get your crown. We need some praise Jesus music up in this place! Bishop Wilkes crosses over to Dave who is standing back f the happy reunion. Greets him with a warm handshake.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP WILKES
dialogues.text: Wonderful to see you in church, Dave. Sister Wilkes and I been prayin’ for you every day.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I know Mama Clark been givin’ you the four-one-one since the accident.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP WILKES
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. But we haven’t just been prayin’ since the accident. I been prayin’ for you since the day I married you and Clarice. (winking at them) Anybody I tie the knot for gets on my special list. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Which takes Dave aback. Bishop notices the pain in his ey

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: I hope you know we’re always here for you. Twenty-four-seven. If God's family is only for Sundays, then we a pretty flimsy family.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (thinking about this) That's straight, Bishop. Thanks. Dave watches as the Bishop crosses off, and we begin HEAR a kicking Gospel tune, perhaps something like Kirk Frankl “BLESSING IN THE STORM” which will carry us through:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A) A vibrant church choir in their colorful robes in all their wonderful glory, singing the song we’re hearing. B) A young girl singing a solo in the middle of the numbe C) Michelle and Todd lifting their hands in praise as the song continues. D) Bishop Wilkes preaching the word with authority. He wi his brow and his tears as he preaches. That’s what happen when the Holy Ghost comes over a prophet. E) Mama speaks back the Bishop as he makes a point she li F) Clarice looks up at the cross at the front of the chur Being in church does her heart good. F) Dave staring straight ahead, thinking. Distracted. And as the SONG CONCLUDES, we’ll...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As services are letting out, Dave escorts Clarice and Mam into the sunshine where they AD LIB well wishes with seve parishioners. Colorful, eccentric, Carmen McAtee spots th and crosses over excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: My Lord, can I get a witness over here? Look at you, Clarice. It’s good to see you in church, sister. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Hi, Carmen. Nice to see you, too. As Carmen engages Clarice, we’ll ADJUST to FIND Dave. He turns and spots something that gets his attention. DAVE’S POV A Caucasian WOMAN with her back turned to us. From this angle, her curvy build and hairstyle look exactly like somebody we’ve seen before. She’s just cleaned up in a Sunday dress and high-heels.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: A smile grows on Dave’s face. He can’t believe it. He tap the woman on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Julie? The woman spins around. It’s not Julie -- not even close. In fact, she’s a little ugly for somebody so shapely.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (surprised, disappointed) Sorry. I thought you were somebody else. Looking for a quick escape, Dave sees Michelle’s husband, Todd, and takes the opportunity to get real friendly. ADJ to find Clarice and Mama. Dave’s little faux pas hasn’t b lost on them. They trade a look, before Clarice puts on a smile for another well-wisher who has come over to greet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama has prepared one of her traditional Sunday Dinners w all the fixings -- turkey, stuffing and sweet potato pie. Only there’s not much talk going on as they eat in silenc

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: That was some real “soul food” we got in church today. We need to start goin’ more often. But Dave hasn’t really heard her. His mind is elsewhere. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Pass them Butter Beans, baby. Clarice silently pushes the bowl of beans his direction. can feel Mama’s eyes on her, but chooses not to look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That evening, Dave is brushing his teeth, while Clarice i rubbing the scars on her leg with some Vitamin E cream. Clarice takes a deep breath for the courage to say someth that has been on her mind.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: This scares me, David.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: What scares you?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: This. The silence between us. It's like we’re a couple of ghosts floating around this place.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I don’t like it either.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I know I been really distant with you since the accident. It’s just I didn’t know how to deal with what I was feelin.’ There were some days I wished I could just stay asleep and never wake up.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: But what scares me even more than that is you pullin’ away from me. Their eyes meet for a long moment. Dave doesn’t know what say. And his lack of a response speaks volumes to Clarice

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want to talk to someone about it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You mean like a counselor? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Would you do that for me? For us? Dave sits next to her on the bed and pulls her into his a

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Sure, baby.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I just want us to go back to the way it was before the accident. Before it all got messed up. But as Dave continues to hold her, the doubt in his eyes things have been messed up for a lot longer than she thin

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: INT. EMMANUEL FELLOWSHIP CHURCH —- COUNSELING OFFICE - DA We’1ll CLOSE ON a painting which depicts a rather-dark complexioned Jesus, and then we’1ll PAN ACROSS several fr diplomas with a lot of “PHD” this and “MARRIAGE & FAMILY” that and all bearing a name: “CARMEN MCATEE.” And then we FIND a very uncomfortable Dave and Clarice sitting on a leather couch across from Carmen. She has a clipboard on lap and is wearing an especially colorful lady’s dashiki.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: I want to give both of you some love for having the courage to come in today. It means you want to make your marriage work. And frankly that isn’t easy these days. Dave and Clarice both nod, awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Clarice, let’s start with you. Why don’t you give your view of what’s going on in your relationship.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Well, since the accident I know I’ve been depressed and we haven’t talked very much. It just seems like our whole marriage Dave was always Johnny on the spot with me. But lately, he seems distracted... like he’s somewhere else. Dave just stares at her. Can’t believe what he’s hearing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: How can you say that? I been by your side through this whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I’m not talking about physically. I’m talking about emotionally.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Well, maybe somebody’s gettin’ in the way of that.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: What do you mean by that, Dave. Dave glances at Clarice and she flashes him a “don’t go there” look. Dave pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Never mind. This little exchange wasn’t lost on Carmen.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: You know, this works better if we’re all honest with each another. Dave looks at Clarice. This time she doesn’t meet his eye

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: It’s her Mama. She been livin’ with us since Clarice got out the hospital. If I’m “somewhere else,” maybe it’s ‘cause I’m trying to get away from her bein’ all up in my grill about everything.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: That’s not true.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Yes, it is, Boo. No matter what I do, I can’t please the woman. And it ain’t just since this accident. It's been our whole marriage.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Well, maybe we should talk about why Mama is displeased. Like your lack of discipline when it comes to takin’ care of business with your building maintenance company. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: It ain’t no building maintenance company. Don’t make it out like it’s better than it is. I’ma glorified janitor. If I’m always buggin’ over it, it’s ‘cause I hate every damn minute of it.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Dave, if you hate it so much, why keep doing it?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Ask her. Clarice looks at Carmen hoping she’1ll be an ally in this

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: He was a high school coach making twenty-six-thousand dollars a year. If we were ever gonna be able to move up in the world, he needed to be more ambitious. So we had him start his own company.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Who is we?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Us. Him and me. Dave just rolls his eyes on that one.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Unless you Shaquille O'Neal, there ain’t room for fun and games for a black man. A black man has to work ten times harder just to get to the starting line.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Even if it means havin’ to give up what you love?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Yes. Where were you goin’ with it, David? You were a junior varsity coach for ten years. I’m sorry to say this, baby, but ain’t nobody at the U.T. was blowin’ up your phone to come coach the Longhorns. This one hurts. Dave looks away from her, ashamed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Dave, what was it you loved best about coaching?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (fighting his emotions) Bein’ with them boys. Helpin’ them get past the curveballs life was throwin’ at ‘em. Helpin’ them believe they could be somebody.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: You mean, kind of like what a daddy is supposed to do with a son? Dave looks up at her sharply. A light comes on for him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Yeah, just like that. But now Clarice is rolling her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Oh, please. Let’s not drag out that tired old topic.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: What topic is that? Clarice seems frozen by the question.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Say it, Clarice. Another long beat before it all comes gushing out.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Fine. You wanna talk about it? I know exactly what you after. Every time, you put your hands on me, I know what you want. You want babies. Family.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Because we been over it a million times. It’s not what I want. I’m not ready to give up all the places I wanna go in life. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Besides, look at us, trying to keep our marriage together. You think a baby’s gonna solve our problems? Dave looks at her for a wounded moment.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I used to. But now I don’t know. This is tough thing for Clarice to hear.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Okay, I know this is painful, but I think we’re getting somewhere. But both Dave and Clarice’s faces say they are not so sur

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. CLARICE’S CADILLAC - TRAVELING - DAY Dave and Clarice ride along in their own raw spaces, not saying anything. Some NEWSTALK SHOW, playing on the radio is suddenly interrupted by a long TONE, and then:

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (OVER RADIO)
dialogues.text: This is a test of the emergency alert system. This is only a test. If this had been an actual emergency, an official message would follow. But neither Dave or Clarice seems to have noticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brock is in the dugout speaking on his cell phone while D is hitting infield-outfield practice to the boys in the b

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Thank you, ma’am. I’11 let him know. Brock hangs up his phone and gives a sigh.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Brock sidles up to Dave just as he hits a long outfield f

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: What his mama say? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: He’s harassing the kid now. She’s afraid to let him come to practice.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (beat, frustrated) What’s that fool tryin’ to do? Guarantee his kid turns out just like him? He calls out to Jaylen in the outfield.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jaylen, move to second. Carlos ain’t comin. Just then, Brock notices something o.s., chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Either somebody missed the turn to the good side of the tracks or we got company. Dave follows his line of sight to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smiling Julie and Bryson striding toward us, waving, call

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: Hey, Coach!

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: If it’s possible for a black man to blanche, Dave does.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Lord almighty, I never thought they’d actually come.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: That's the physical therapist? Dave nods. Brock checks her out -- bumper to bumper.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, I’m feelin’ a little leg cramp. You think she’d rub it out?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (irritated) Put your tongue back in your mouth, fool. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Julie and Bryson arrive at home plate.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Hi, Dave. I hope you don’t mind, but he wouldn’t take “maybe next” week for an answer.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: No, that’s cool. That’s great. Bryson, glad you could make it. Brock quickly bumps past Dave, offering his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: You must be Julie. Dave and Clarice talk about you all the time. I’m Brock, assistant coach and Dave's best friend. I’m sure he’s told you all about me.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: (blankly) No... sorry. But nice to meet you anyway. Just then fat Marcus calls out to Dave from first base.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Yo, coach. Who’s the little soda cracker? Dave offers Julie an apologetic look, then calls to the b

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: This is Bryson Sawyer. He’s gonna be workin’ out with us today.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: (trying out his cool) What’s crackin’ ya’1l?

dialogues.speaker: VARIOUS REACTIONS
dialogues.text: Around the diamond -- from stunned to skeptical to jaws hanging open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryson is now standing at second base, wearing a glove, looking ready for action, but unsure of what to do. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: All right, Bryson. I’m gonna hit you a ground ball and then you go to first with it.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: Gotcha, Coach. Dave hits a roller to Bryson. Dave hits it so softly, it dies on the dirt about five feet in front of him. Bryson walks over, picks it up and tosses it to the first basema

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Good pick up, Bryson! Way to read the ball! Bryson looks a little disappointed and some of the boys a snickering in their gloves.

dialogues.speaker: DESHAWN
dialogues.text: Yo, Coach, what is this? Tee-ball? My ‘lil sister could have made that play and she blind in one eye. Which ignites a round of CACKLES across the diamond. Dave promptly hits a scorching line-drive at Deshawn, which he to duck in order to avoid getting his taken off.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Maybe we should try out your ‘lil sister at shortstop. Deshawn gives Dave a worried look, then turns to Bryson

dialogues.speaker: DESHAWN
dialogues.text: Nice play, little white dude.

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: Julie is watching and her concern turns into a smile.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Okay, Bryson, infield fly. Dave hits a tall pop fly out to second base. As Bryson tr to get a read on it, he moves one way, then another, then turns in a circle trying to keep his eye on the ball. Finally he sticks up his glove and the ball falls right o HIS HEAD. It dazes him momentarily, but he recovers quick (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: I’m okay. I’m okay. (looking around confused) Are there like millions of gnats flying around my head? Dave and Brock exchange concerned looks.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Hustle in here. Coach Brock gonna break open the ice pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryson is in the on-deck circle with a bat in his hand. B has just finished throwing batting practice to Darius. Da plops a batting helmet down on his Bryson’s head, smiling

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: We don’t any more of them gnats. Bryson reciprocates with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, get in there. Keep your eye on the ball. Level swing. Bryson step in the batter’s box. Out in the field, lots o AD LIB CHATTER and RAZZING from the players: “Hey batter- batter-batter” with “Yo, Twinkle Toes” in there somewhere

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Here we go, Bryson. Nothing fancy. Brock winds up and fires the ball to the catcher, Marcus. Bryson doesn’t even get the bat off his shoulder, causing chorus of BOOS from the field. Jaylen calls from second b

dialogues.speaker: JAYLEN
dialogues.text: What you waitin’ for, batter? An invitation in the mail?

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: I thought it was outside.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Boy, that was so down the middle Amtrak coulda sold seats on it. Brock winds up and fires in another pitch. This time it i outside and Bryson swings right through it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now that was outside.

dialogues.speaker: DARIUS
dialogues.text: Yo, Twinkle Toes, where coach find you -- cheerleader camp?

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: Now Julie is concerned, and biting her nails nervously.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: This time Brock does the reprimanding, glaring at Darius.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Hey, Darius, wasn’t that you who missed the cutoff throw Saturday and threw the ball into the stands? I‘1ll bet that old lady still has a bump on her forehead. Now Darius is the target of derision and trash talk, like “Oh, boy, he tagged you straight up,” etc.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Let’s go, Bryson, you can do this. Focus on the ball like it’s the finish line in that pool. Bryson gives him a nod, steps back into the box. Brock st onto on the mound, winds up and we'll go into SLOW-MOTION

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: A) The ball comes sailing in. B) Bryson narrows his eyes. C) Here comes his bat. D) Here comes the ball. E) The bat impacts with the ball with a loud CRACK. F) There goes the ball. A rocket shot. G) Marcus throws off his catchers mask, astonished look o his face. H) Darius can clearly be seen mouthing the word “shit.” I) Brock follows the trajectory with his eyes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: J) Julie has her hand over her mouth, holding her breath. K) Dave, with a very pleased look on his face, as L) The ball clears the low fence in right field. Home run We'll come back to REAL TIME as Julie cheers from the sta

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Whoo-hoo! Bryson! Put a hurt on that ball! Dave and Brock rush over and give Bryson excited high-fiv

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Now that’s what I’m talking about!

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: You went yard, dude! I can’t even go yard! But it’s his peers who really count. Very black Marcus offers his hand to very white Bryson.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: You for real, dawg.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: Thanks, man. A moment that makes Dave and Brock very proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Practice is over. In the dugout, several of the players a chatting quietly with Bryson. He’s the man. And we’ll ADJUST to FIND Dave and Brock stowing equipment near home plate as Julie crosses to them.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I can’t tell you both how much this meant to him today. (looking at Dave) And to me. A look not lost on Dave. Brock looks up at the sky, sighs

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: You know, Julie, it’s starting to get dark, and this isn’t the safest neighborhood. Why don’t you let me walk you and Bryson to your car. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Uh, sure... okay. (looking again at Dave) Thanks again, Dave.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (long beat, meaning it) My pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Julie, I was thinking... if you ever need to reach us... As Brock leads Julie away, he hands her a business card.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... in case Bryson wants to come to practice again. Or if you ever just want to talk about, you know... baseball... you can always give me a ring on my cell phone. As Dave watches them go, shaking his head, Brock turns an gives him a really annoying wink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re MOVING through a trash-strewn corridor and FIND a b up-looking door. Nasty-sounding RAP plays somewhere o.s. BLACK HAND knocks on the door. After a few beats, it open and a red-eyed Darnell stands there, shirt off, tatted up Behind him, marijuana smoke hangs in the air and we can s the “ho” we saw earlier. She buttons her blouse, adjusts skirt so as not to show off the goods.

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: What the hell you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave and he has a loaded-for-bear look in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: If you wanna beef, G, then let’s get it on. But don’t kill your boy’s future ‘cause you got a problem with me.

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: Ain’t none of your goddamn business what I do with my boy. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You ain’t nothin’ but a minstrel show. Go put on some shoe-polish, nigger. Your white’s showing.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: How you gonna hate on a brother just for gettin’ his shit together? Darnell has no answer for this. Just keeps staring.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You better knock that victim chip off your shoulder or someday Carlos gonna end up where ya'll did.

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: (eyes narrowing) Your punk-ass would know all about that, wouldn't it?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: When you gonna stop blamin’ the world for not punchin’ your college ticket, Darnell? Nobody forced you to sling no crack. That ain’t nobody else’s shit. It’s all on you. This bites. Hard. Darnell’s eyes are cold and hard.

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: Fuck you. So that’s how it is. Dave shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: From now on, I’m pickin’ Carlos up for practice. And you better stay the hell out of the way. Dave turns walks away from Darnell.

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: Next time you come up in here, nigger, come strapped ‘cause I’m gonna drop your ass. Dave never looks back. Darnell slams his door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A three-story housing unit. All broken glass and pimped-u rides out front. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dave exits through a door with a sign: “NO ANIMALS ALLOWE He trades looks with a young black crew on the stoop. The look at him like “who’s this alien mofo?”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Dave enters, Clarice and Mama are clearing the dinne dishes. Dave and Clarice trade a look which says they are talking to each other. Dave’s a man of few words right no

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: You want me to warm you up a plate.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: No thanks. Dave’s cell phone RINGS. He looks at the caller ID.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s work. I’1l take it outside. As Dave exits, a slight look of alarm comes over Clarice.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (OVER PHONE)
dialogues.text: Dave, forgive me for intruding...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryson has his head jacked into an Ipod and is getting hi dance on, as Julie drives and talks on her cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: (into phone) But this kid is higher than a kite, and he’s not gonna give me any peace until I ask you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave paces as he talks on his cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Ask me what?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: He says he owes you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Tell him he can pay me back by getting to the Olympics someday.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (OVER PHONE)
dialogues.text: I don’t think that’1ll be enough. In the car, Bryson pulls off his earphones, grabs the pho

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: Coach, after your game Saturday, can you come to the Swim Stadium?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: You taught me how to hit a baseball. Now I gotta teach you how to freestyle. Julie grabs the phone back, rolls her eyes at Bryson.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: So what do you say, Coach?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (chuckling) I say the boy could sell fried chicken at a family reunion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice has come to the kitchen window and is looking out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While we can’t make out Dave’s conversation through the window, he seems to be chatting happily with someone.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Clarice turns and sees Mama watching her from the doorway

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: I don’t know what that man has on his brain right now, baby, but livin’ with your raggedy ass daddy all them years... I got a guess. Mama exits to the living room. Clarice doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave is prone on his stomach on a massage table in a room by candles and accented with SOFT, SENSUAL MUSIC (somethi like “SEXUAL HEALING”). We TRAVEL from his contented face along his side to his hind parts, covered by a small towe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His back is covered with oil, and now petite, yet strong WHITE FEMALE HANDS begin running down his naked back in a suggestive (but shot very discreet) way. Her fingers ling at his towel line teasingly. We catch a glimpse of a shor sexy silk robe. Dave moans as she whispers in his ear. Da then turns over on his back and looks up at us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sexy woman is Julie. She smiles seductively and begin to loosen the belt of her robe.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Dave closes his eyes, receiving some mysterious pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re CLOSE ON DAVE’S face and he is being shaken awake, we WIDEN to see Clarice is the one doing the shaking.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: What’s wrong? Why you shakin’ me?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: You was moanin’. I thought you was havin’ a heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I... I musta been dreamin.’ Clarice lifts the sheets, looks south of his stomach. A h of disgust glints in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I can see what kind of dream you was havin’.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (busted, embarrassed) Go back to sleep. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He turns his back to cover his arousal. She stares at him for a long moment, then it hits her. She turns to see a c phone on her night stand. Silently, she opens the phone a pushes a button.

dialogues.speaker: PHONE
dialogues.text: We’re looking at the “CALL LOG” screen and the most recen call on the list is from: “SAWYER, JULIE.”

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Clarice stares at the screen for a long beat, then quietl returns the phone to the night stand, falls into her pill

dialogues.speaker: BED
dialogues.text: The two of them, their backs turned to each other, both awake. Both thinking, worrying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice, dressed sharply in an attractive pants suit, ent with the aid of her cane. When her co-workers see her, th begin to applaud and many offer hugs and AD LIBBED greeti Michelle is waiting for her at the end with open arms.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: Girl, you a sight for sore eyes. Clarice offers her a modest, grateful smile.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Time to get back to work. INT. HASTINGS REAL ESTATE - CLARICE’S OFFICE - DAY - LATE Michelle is excitedly bringing Clarice up to speed. Clari watches out the window as she listens.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: (handing her files) So I managed to get the Hodsons, Lowrys and Svensons lined up to see properties this weekend. (saving best for last) And check this. The Reids made an offer through another agent and it fell out of escrow. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Clarice doesn’t react. Michelle looks puzzled. She pulls up a chair and locks in her girlfriend radar.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, girl, where is your head at? Clarice turns and looks at her blankly.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry... ?

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: I just told you the Reids are still in play, and you look like you on Mars. What is goin’ on?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: (trying to cover) It’s nothing. I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: Don’t make a sister go Oprah on your ass. Clarice takes a deep breath, then decides to give it up. burden mists up in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I think Dave is steppin’ out on me.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: (gasping, disbelief) Oh, honey, are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I can see it in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: Hmm-hmm. It’s always in them eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I don’t know what to do. I know what Mama would tell me to do. What she herself did... walk out and not look back. I feel like throwin’ up just goin’ there. Michelle moves in closer to her.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: Now you listen to me. I ain’t lettin’ you Wait to Exhale on me, girl. Dave’s too good a man to lose. (MORE)
The (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Last thing you wanna do is something you can’t take back. (beat, soberly) Trust me, I know.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me Todd be tappin’ on something.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: (hanging head) No. It was me who was tappin.’

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I had no idea, Michelle.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: Ain’t somethin’ a sister wants in the church bulletin. The reason I’m tellin’ you to hang onto your marriage no matter what is because that’s what my man did for me. I was out gettin’ my freak on, and he could have kicked me to the curb. (hangs head, tears coming) But he didn’t. He prayed that God would fill the need I had in me that was causing me to stray. He prayed for his prodigal wife to come home. And for the forgiveness he would need if I ever did.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: And did he? Did he forgive you?

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: It was hard. It took a long time. But that’s a secret about how God works. He makes possible what the world says is impossible. My husband didn’t give up on me, and I don’t ever want to sacrifice his heart like that again. Clarice looks at her for a long moment, tears welling up. OFF Michel

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I’m glad for you, Michelle. But I don’t think I have it in me to do what Todd did. le’s worried look --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. DAVE’S PANEL VAN - DAY Dave is parked on the street out front of the Downtown Aquatics Club. He watches as families enter the stadium. He sighs and starts his engine, but changes his mind, tur off the key. He screws up his courage and opens his door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Electricity in the air. Packed bleachers. Bryson comes out of the locker room in his brightly colored warm-ups a makes his way over to wear Julie and some of the other parents are waiting with his teammates.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Babe, you sure you’re not taking on too much, swimming five events?

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: It’s regionals. Coach needs me. Julie pulls him in for a hug and a hair-tousle.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hope you don’t mind a little extra pressure. Julie and Bryson spin to see Dave standing there.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: No way! Coach, you made it!

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You swimmin’ for the gold, young man. I wouldn’t miss it. Now the color drains from Bryson’s face, replaced by drea

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: I’m not feeling so good. Excuse me... I don’t wanna hurl on you. He rushes off to the locker room. Dave looks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: (not to worry) He does that all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave and Julie are sitting together in the packed stands. HEAR the DRONE of an AIRPLANE overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A single-engine plane trailing an advertising banner read “THE GREATEST TRAGEDY IS INDIFFERENCE... THE RED CROSS.”

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: But Dave and Julie are too engrossed in the meet to notic

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (OVER P.A.)
dialogues.text: Fifty freestyle. Heat seven. Swimmers to the blocks. They watch excitedly as Bryson makes his way to his lane. Dave yells out his support.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Yo, Bryson, remember you King King up in this pool! Some of the parents around them stare at Dave, annoyed. H may be a little over the top, but Julie appreciates it.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: You know, his father has never once seen him swim.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: His father’s a stupid man.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I’m afraid Bryson won’t be able to look you in the eye if he doesn’t place in this race.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Please, this boy does not need to impress me. He’s already a champion just bein’ here.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I know that. But try convincing him. And the sound of the STARTER GUN will take us into: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: A) We're UNDER WATER as Bryson hits the pool and we'll tr his progress from this angle for several strokes. B) And now we’re at the edge of the pool looking across a eight lanes and watching the swimmers. Bryson and another boy are just a nose ahead of the pack. C) Dave and Julie are watching breathless as parents all around CHEERING and SCREAMING. D) UNDER WATER, Bryson hits the turn wall one stroke behi the leader and a few strokes ahead of the next best swimm Bryson’s flip turn is perfect. E) Now we’re half way back to the finish line and Bryson begins to turn on the afterburners. He catches the leader F) CLOSE ON FROM ABOVE Bryson and the leader. Nose and no G) Dave is now cheering with the rest of the parents, but Julie has her eyes closed. Can’t bear to watch. H) At the wall, it’s a photo finish for Bryson and the ot swimmer. Too close for us to call.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (OVER P.A.)
dialogues.text: Judge’s ruling... winner heat seven... by two-one-hundredths of a second... Bryson Sawyer. I) In the stands, Dave and Julie go bananas, hugging spontaneously before pulling apart, looking slightly awkw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A proud Coach Spinello is already wrapping Bryson in a to

dialogues.speaker: COACH SPINELLO
dialogues.text: You got these high school boys looking over their shoulders. No mercy, right Kiddo?

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: No mercy. Julie and Dave rush up. Coach looks at Julie, dead seriou

dialogues.speaker: COACH SPINELLO
dialogues.text: You need to start thinking Junior Olympics for this boy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I will. The coach crosses off. Dave pulls Bryson into a bear hug.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Now that’s what I’m talkin’ about! Boy, you were off the chain!

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: Thanks, Coach. But I still got four more races this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: First, call me “Dave.” I ain’t the coach today. You the coach. (holding his chest) And if you expect me to sit through four more races like that, I’m gonna need me some heart pills. Bryson is beaming. So is Julie.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: Mom, coach says I need to carbo- load before my next heat. Can Dave go with us to Grazianos?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Honey, I’m sure Dave’s has a busy -- Dave cuts her off with a hand on her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I’d love to go. (puts arm around Bryson) All the carbs you can eat. My treat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re TIGHT ON some n.d. video game. Lots of BEEPS and BELLS, and WIDEN to see Bryson and a few of the other swimmers in their warm ups, dropping quarters in a wall f of machines in a pizza joint with a family atmosphere.

dialogues.speaker: TABLE
dialogues.text: Dave and Julie are chatting freely, picking at the last slivers of a pizza together in a quiet booth. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: So if you loved being a high school coach so much, why did you quit? Dave looks at her for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You the second person who’s asked me that this week, and I don’t have a good answer.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Well, if you ask me, life is too short not to follow your bliss.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: My what?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Bliss. Your thing. Your passion. The one thing you do better than anything else. I’ve always believed you should do what you love, and not worry about the money. If you do what you were born to do, the money will take care of itself. (remembering something) Course, that hasn’t exactly panned out with this cheap-frigging-HMO I work for, but you get my point. Dave has to chuckle at this. She gazes at him long moment

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dave, I hope you won't take this the wrong way, but as a single woman, I’m sort of an expert.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: On what?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Good men. The “’Til Death Do Us Part” type. The protect and cherish type. Me and my single friends sit around bitching about how all the guys like you are already taken. (sighing sadly) Clarice is a lucky woman. She has no idea how hard it is find a man like you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dave thinks a beat, then ventures into taboo territory.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Sometimes I wish I wasn’t... taken. Julie looks at him for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I’m not sure. But I need to find out. They look into each other’s eyes and the implications han the air. A door CHIME RINGING draws their attention to:

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Brock just entering in his best Saturday casual. As he crosses into the restaurant he does a double-take when he sees Dave and Julie looking at him from a private booth.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Dave hangs his head. The moment is over. Brock walks up t their table, surprised, confused.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Dave, what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I could ask you the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: I live across the street. Oh, right. Dave and Julie trade awkward looks. Julie jump up, trying to put her best cover on things.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Nice to see you again, Brock. Bryson invited Dave to his meet. Team ordered too many pizzas and we needed an extra stomach.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Oh. Cool.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I’m gonna go check on the boys. Dave, thanks again for coming. It was really great of you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She offers her hand, and he receives it. It all looks ver harmless, but their touch lingers for longer than it shou Then Julie crosses off. Brock eyes Dave suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: You wanna tell me what the hell’s goin’ on here, brother. Dave doesn't like his tone, but doesn’t want to play game

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Don’t get all self-righteous with me. Not with the way you was droolin’ all over her at practice the other day.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Hey, time out. That’s not the point. I get to drool all I want. I’m not the one who’s married.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: What are you -- my mama?

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: (beat, that hurt) No, I’m the guy who’s supposed to have my best friend’s back, and I don’t want to see him do something stupid and screw up his life. But Dave is numb, even to this.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: My life’s already screwed up. I appreciate your concern, but I don’t want your advice on this. As Dave crosses off, Brock watches him sadly, wounded.

dialogues.speaker: ANGLE
dialogues.text: FOLLOW Dave over to Julie and Bryson at the video games.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: Hey, Dave, you want to get your brains blown out in Neo Geo?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (chuckling) I’ll have to pass on that. And I’m gonna need a raincheck on the rest of your races this afternoon. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (looking at Julie) I got me some stuff to work out.

dialogues.speaker: BRYSON
dialogues.text: That’s cool. How about next week? I got an AAU meet. I’11 bring my gold from today to show you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I’d like that, son. Dave ruffles his hair. He gives Julie one last look, befo exiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave enters somberly. The curtains are drawn shut and the only light comes from lit several candles. Dave lays his cell phone on the nightstand, then sits on the edge of hi bed and puts his head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You didn’t notice the candles. Dave looks up to see Clarice in sexy nothing of a nighty, poised on her cane near her vanity. Dave is not only surprised to see her -- but surprised to see her like thi

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Reesie...

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: (best come-hither voice) Remember the candles when we first got married? They were always my signal. “Green light, baby. I’m gonna whip somethin’ on you.” Clarice begins to limp slowly toward Dave with her cane, wicked scars more visible than ever on her bare leg. Dave looks at her, deeply conflicted.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Are you sure you wanna do this? She gingerly climbs on the bed and begins rubbing his shoulders. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I sent Mama on an errand. We need this. I think it’s why we arguin’ so much. We need to get back to the lovin’ part of our marriage.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: What about your leg?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I’ll be careful. She begins to kiss him on the neck. But he doesn’t respon

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, baby, I want you so much. She tries to nibble on his ear. This time, he stops her.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Reesie, you don’t have to do this. She pulls back on the bed, wounded, desperate, paranoid.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: It’s my scars. I’11 put some make up on ‘em so you don’t have to look at ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: It’s not your scars. Now her hurt turns to betrayal and explosive rage.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: It's because you having an affair, isn’t it, you bastard?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: With Julie Sawyer.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: That ain’t true.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: You think I haven’t noticed the little phone calls? The way you look for her in a crowd? The way you light up when she’s around? What is the truth if you ain’t hittin’ it with that woman? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dave looks at her with a mix of confusion, guilt in his e She’s not wrong. After a long moment, he sighs.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: It ain’t gone as far as an affair. But I can’t lie to you. Things ain’t been right for us in a long time... and I do feel somethin’ for this girl. For Julie. Big tears of resignation form in Clarice’s eyes, and she covers herself with the bedding -- as if ashamed of her b

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: It’s worse than affair. She’s taken your heart from me, and that ain't somethin’ I can do anything about. Neither of them says anything for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are we over, David?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (eyes welling up) I don’t know, Reesie. I gotta do some thinking. Dave turns and exits quietly. Clarice falls back into her pillow, sobbing. And we'll FIND his cell phone resting on the night stand and begin HEARING a soulful R&B tune (per something like Luther Vandross’ “I WHO HAVE NOTHING”).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave returns to the empty gym and begins shooting hoops a by himself. And he pushes himself really hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryson steps up to the blocks for his final heat as Julie looks on proudly in the b.g. And we'll see the PUFF OF SM from the starter’s gun and Bryson dives into liquid blue.  103.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave makes a basket and turns to see someone else there w the same agenda as him. It’s Darnell. They stand facing each other for a long moment... dueling with their eyes. Dave finally fires the ball to him -- an invitation to a little one-on-one game. Darnell smirks. Let’s do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie’s in the bleachers, cheering, screaming, willing Br onto victory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darnell tries to fake Dave with the ball, but Dave doesn’ for it, so Darnell drives right through him hard. Dave fa on his back, slamming his head on the court and Darnell scores. Dave pops back, up rubbing his head, and holds ou his hand for the ball. Now it’s his turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re TRACKING CLOSE on Bryson as he swims for all he’s worth. With every turn of his head for a breath, we see confidence, determination to win in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama enters the room with a shopping back and a rosy disposition. Then she sees Clarice, eyes red with tears, her bathrobe sitting disconsolately on the floor next to bed. Mama’s face falls. She knows what this is about. She been there, done that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave is driving the lane. When he hits the free-throw lin he leaps toward the basket, Michael Jordan style, higher higher until his knees are almost at the level of Darnell head. And as Dave slams the ball through the basket, his foot catches Darnell square on the face. When Dave lands, Darnell is wiping blood from his mouth, smiling at him.  104.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re still TRACKING Bryson as he makes his final flip tu And then suddenly we’re trying to catch back up him becau he has picked up his pace. And now we can see that he is full length ahead of the next best swimmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave makes a desperate attempt to cut off Darnell’s path the basket, but misses and slams into the wall -- leaving blood and sweat marks on the wall. Smiling, he turns back Darnell with his own war-wounds -- a bloody nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As parents and his teammates are rooting him on along the edge of the pool in the b.g., Bryson is all by himself ou front of the pack and he hits the wall for the win.

dialogues.speaker: BLEACHERS
dialogues.text: Julie goes wild with joy and begins hugging everybody aro her. But then Julie feels a need to look down at the pool

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowd has gathered around Bryson’s lane. Something's wrong. Bryson’s not getting out of the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darnell is dribbling the ball when Dave bats it out of hi hand. They both go diving after the ball at the same time and both get their hands on it. It’s what’s called a “jum ball” and they both roll around on the floor, wrestling e other for the ball. Finally, they both look at each other realizing how foolish this all is... and begin laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie is panicking as she tries to fight through the crow And then the gauntlet opens up and she sees Bryson on the pool deck. A small group of people are hovering over him A wet, drenched Coach Spinello is pushing on his chest, o and over, yelling something, tears rolling down his face. And a horror she’s never felt before washes over Julie’s entire being.  105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama helps a disconsolate Clarice into her bed and pulls covers up. And then notices a flashing light on the night stand -- Dave’s cell phone. She goes over and looks at it

dialogues.speaker: PHONE
dialogues.text: The caller ID display reads: “SAWYER, JULIE.”

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Mama scowls. She presses POWER button and turns the phone off. She sets it back down with a self-righteous look. An as she does, our SONG and SERIES OF SCENES will end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave and Darnell are bloodied, bruised and completely spe from their duel and sitting in heaps against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I’d call that a draw, homey.

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: Man to man, nobody listenin’... who gets that scholarship if we was still back in the day?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (beat, thinking) You, dawg. Hands-down. World always gonna love a shooter more than a big man. Plus, you just a better player. Darnell savors these words for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: So you think all the shit I been through is my own fault?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Shit comes down on everybody. You can either let it keep you on your ass. Or you can choose to get past it. To beat it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: What makes you Dr. Phil on the subject? Dave sucks in a bitter breath, reminded of where he at.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Trust me, you ain’t the only one with problems. In some ways, you got no idea how good you got it.

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: You talkin’ about Carlos.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You ever heard the story about the man who had no shoes?

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: He felt sorry for himself until he met a man who had no feet. (with deep longing) Don’t waste a minute to be that boy’s daddy. It’s the only thing that really matters in this life. Hundred years from now, you gonna be dead and gone. But Carlos gonna have a grandson who remembers his great-grandpappy, Darnell Gooden. You still got a chance to make that a good memory.

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: (nodding soberly) That’s some real shit, ya’ll. And here I been jealous of you all these years for gettin’ that scholarship instead of me.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Brother, I'd trade that scholarship and everything I’ve ever had for a son like Carlos. Now Darnell has a question for Dave.

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: So when life knock you on your ass, how do you get back up? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dave is taken aback by the question, and right now, it’s clear he doesn’t have a damn clue how to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daylight has ebbed as Dave walks in slowly, depleted and defeated, still wearing is sweats. Mama is there in the living room, standing by Clarice’s side, waiting for him. There’s fire in her eyes that we haven’t seen before.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
