dialogues.text: Sit your butt down, young man. We gonna have a little come-to-Jesus meetin’.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Mama, let’s not do this.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Let her speak, Clarice. She always had her own vote in this marriage. Why change things now? Clarice turns and glares at Dave.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: Now you listen to me. However you gettin’ your itch scratched by this little white hoochie-mama Ho, it ends right now, or you can pack your philanderin’ ass up and get outta Dodge.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Mama, it’s more complicated than that.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: (never takes off him) No it ain’t, Reesie. What is wrong with you, boy? You got this beautiful black wife standing over here, and you do the bumpty-bump with a white girl? You must be addicted to BET and them foul- mouthed rappers and their nasty little white fly girls. Dave has kept his mouth shut as long as he’s going to. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Now it’s your turn you listen to me, you angry, bitter, man-hating old woman. Whatever is happenin’ between me and Julie Sawyer -- and I ain’t saying I even know what that is -- it has nothin’ to do with her damn skin color. Mama takes off her wig, puts up her dukes. Fighting mad.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: Where is that skank? I’m gonna knock both ya’lls into next week. Just then, the house PHONE RINGS. Dave and Mama glare at each other. It RINGS again. Finally, Clarice sighs and goes to answer it. Mama puts her wig back on, still fumin

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: (answering phone) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK, (OVER PHONE)
dialogues.text: (somber, sober) Clarice, it’s Brock. I need to speak with Dave.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: It’s not a good time right now, Brock.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK, (OVER PHONE)
dialogues.text: This is really important, Clarice. There’s been an accident.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Accident? Which changes things and perks up Mama’s ear. Clarice loo at Dave with deep concern and hands the phone to him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (into phone) What is this? Who had an accident?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brock is pacing a room full of empty waiting chairs with cell phone to his ear. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Julie has been trying to call. She finally tracked me down when she couldn’t reach you on your cell. Dave checks his pockets, realizes he doesn’t have his

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Why? What happened?

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: There’s no easy way to say this, man, but Bryson... he’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Bryson’s gone? What the hell does that mean? 109. phone. Despite what’s happening between them, Clarice pulls in c to listen with him.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: In his final race, he went into the wall too hard. He hit his head. They tried to revive him... but he never regained consciousness. Dave feels like he’s been punched in the gut. Clarice pul away from the phone, covering her mouth with her hand.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Oh, sweet Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: I’m at All Saints. I think you better get over here. Dave slowly hangs up the phone. He’s in shock.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I’1l go with you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I want to go with you. Just ‘cause I have a problem with that woman doesn’t mean I can’t look past it at a time like this. Can a black man look red? If so, Dave does right now. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (exploding) For God sake, Clarice, what kind of man do you think I am? You think I’m gonna go over there and get my flirt on with a woman who just lost her only child?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean it like --

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (hating this even more) You know what? Hell no. I don’t want you coming with me. Not if gonna do me like that. Dave grabs a jacket off a coat rack and starts for the do Clarice is frozen. Now it’s Mama who fires the big gun.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: Young man, I don’t care if Sweet Judy Blue Eyes lost a whole damn bus load of children, if you walk out that door, Clarice will not be here when you come back. Dave stares straight at Clarice. She does not meet his ey

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Clarice has to do what she has to do. And so do I. With that, Dave walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave has caught up with Brock and they are weaving in and of hospital staff traffic.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: She’s pretty messed up, bro. Her parents are driving up from Houston. The hospital didn’t know what to do with her because she refused to leave until the funeral home comes for the... for Bryson.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Where is she now? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Only place I could think of better than the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave enters a quiet little wood and stained-glass refuge the heart of the hospital. Julie is sitting in the front with her head in her hands. When he sees her, Dave’s hear hurts for her.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (softly) Julie? Julie looks at him through red, liquid prisms. She rushes him, sobbing, quaking, her voice hoarse with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Oh, Dave. My baby’s gone. My baby boy is gone. Dave lets himself hold her tight and she takes every bit his warmth, his strength... because she desperately needs

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I know, honey. I am so sorry you couldn’t reach me. I should have been there. At the meet. Maybe I could have done something.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: It all happened so fast. It keeps playing in my head. Over and over. It comes out in gasps and she plays it again n her mind.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s winning the final heat, and I’m screaming louder than I ever have. But he doesn’t get out of the pool right away like he always did. I’m thinking he’s goofing off. Then Coach Spinello is jumping in the water, pulling him onto the deck, pounding on his chest. Then we’re riding in the ambulance and they’re using the paddles on him. breaking down again ( (MORE) g ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He was just lying there with his eyes closed like when I watched him sleep as a baby. His little chest would rise with every breath. So peaceful. But it wasn’t rising anymore. I thought if I could just rock him and sing to him, he would wake up and be okay. Dave holds her even tighter, stroking her hair.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: There’s nothing you could have done for him, honey. But he in God’s arms now. He woke up in God’s arms.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Do you really think so?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I know so, Julie. That boy was made for a better place than this. Just then, Ted and his “assistant” Kate enter the chapel. opposed to his cool, controlled manner the last time he s him, he is now a wet emotional noodle.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Oh, Julie, sweetheart, Kate and I came as soon as we heard. He rushes into Julie’s arms and falls into her arms, sobb It's awkward. Dave and Kate, the outsiders, give each oth an uncomfortable look

dialogues.speaker: TED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How could this be happening? I was going to come to his swim meet. I really was. And then I got hung up on an account. Oh, God, why didn’t I go see him? Now it’s too late. She pushes back from him, and suddenly she has her emotio in check. She is in charge.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Listen to me, Ted. Right now, I don’t give a damn about all your regrets. The only thing that Matters is that we hold it together long enough to honor Bryson the way he deserves to be honored. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: After that, you have the rest of your life to think about what a selfish bastard of a father you were. Ted sobers up quickly. He nods, wiping his eyes. She know he’s right.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: When can we... can I see him?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Tomorrow. They’re gonna have a private viewing for him at funeral home. You can see him then.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Julie, I’m sorry. I really am.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I know. Ted turns and exits the chapel with Kate. As soon as the door closes, Julie crumples into a pew -- as if it took e last bit of her energy to hold things together for Ted. D sits down next to her, puts his arm around her.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dave, what am I gonna do? What am I gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: We gonna get through this, Julie. I promise. And as she turns and sobs on his chest --

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. MAMA’S BUNGLAOW - NIGHT - ESTABLISHING A small, neatly groomed house in a gentrified neighborhoo with a lawn and garden manicured by hand. The kind of pla your very proud grandma would live. Clarice’s Cadillac is the driveway. INT. CLARICE’S CHILDHOOD ROOM - NIGHT The door opens and a hand turns on the light. Mama enters followed by Clarice, and carrying two overnight bags. The room is immaculately preserved, right down to the cheer- leading trophies elementary school pictures on the shelve and the stuffed animals on the bed little girl’s canopy b (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Mama, I need to be at home.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: No, Reesie. Until we can figure out how to get that sorry excuse for a man out of your beautiful house, you gonna stay here where I can look after you.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I’m not ready to do this.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: Yes you are. You a strong, independent woman just the way I raised you. I did it. And you gonna be able to do it, too. Clarice sighs, too weary to argue, and sits down on the b

dialogues.speaker: MAMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now you get settled in. You gonna feel a whole lot better when you have a piece of my famous Sock-It- To-Me cake. Mama exits. Clarice balls up into a fetal position on the bed, clutching onto one of her old Teddy Bears.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DAVE’S PANEL VAN - TRAVELING - NIGHT Julie rides along in numb reflection as Dave drives her h

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I used to drop Bryson off at Sunday School, and he’d come home with all these bible stories. After Ted left, Bryson would pray at night for him, asking God to forgive him. But I haven’t been to church in years. I don’t even know who to ask to do the service. I don’t want Bryson in some musty funeral home. I want to celebrate his life.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: If you don’t mind, I think I know some people who can help. And celebrate is what they do best.  115. EXT. JULIE AND BRYSON’S BUNGLAOW - NIGHT - MOMENT LATER Dave’s van pulls up into Julie’s driveway, where a midsiz car is already parked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Julie gets out of the car, an OLDER COUPLE gets out of sedan and rushes to her. They are her parents, and Julie falls into her mother’s arms, and they both sob right the in the driveway, as Julie’s father tries to comfort them.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Oh, Mommy, he’s gone! What do I do? My Bryson’s gone. And Julie’s father gives Dave a sad nod of thanks, and be ushering his grieving wife and daughter toward the house. Dave knows she’s in safe hands now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave enters quietly. The place is dark, empty, lonely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave walks in slowly and flips on a light. He sees that Clarice’s vanity is open and empty, that some of her dres drawers are open and empty. Without taking his clothes of he slowly lies down on their bed and stares at the ceilin And as he does, we'll begin HEARING the mournful, soulful sounds of a small gospel ensemble singing something like Franklin's “HOLD ME NOW.”

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A carpet of green overlooking the city. A resting place f the dearly departed, dotted with headstones. And we’1ll C DOWN to FIND a grave-side gathering surrounding a casket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as we PAN the very black, singing faces of the GOSPEL ENSEMBLE, we now know who Dave has helped Julie turn to, the song will take us into: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: A) We’re CLOSE ON a lovely casket, and ADJUST to see a beautiful wreath of flowers and then a framed photograph smiling Bryson Sawyer -- his eyes staring straight out at almost immortal. B) We PAN the front row of seated mourners... a red-eyed on one end with Kate standing behind him... then Julie's mother and father, and then finally Julie, with Dave in h best black suit, standing behind her. C) A very sober Coach Spinello and several of Bryson’s teammates, all dressed in their matching swim club warm u file past the casket, and the coach lays Bryson’s gold me atop the casket. D) We PAN the very white FACES of the larger gathering of mourners who have gathered -- friends, extended family, schoolmates -- and two black faces -- Bishop Wilkes, dres in his most colorful, hopeful ministerial robes, and Carm McAtee, with her dreads done up with ribbons. E) Dave turns to see Brock arriving with Darius, Deshawn, Marcus and Jaylen -- all dressed respectfully in dress sh and ties. Dave moves to them and shakes each of their han before embracing Brock in a long hug. F) Brock escorts his little leaguers past the casket, and each one leaves an offering for Bryson -- a bat, a baseba a glove, and finally a team jersey with the name “SAWYER” letters on the back. G) Tears stream down Julie’s face as her son is honored. Dave puts his strong hand on her shoulder for support. Sh reaches up and takes it and holds on for dear life. H) Coach Spinello comes to the front of the gathering and reads from some typed pages -- the eulogy. I) And as the SONG ENDS, so will our SERIES OF SHOTS as Bishop Wilkes now steps up to the casket and faces the gathering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before the Bishop begins, he looks with confusion at Dave standing with Julie’s hand on his. But Dave can’t, or won look at him, so he turns his attention to Julie. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP WILKES
dialogues.text: Julie, as a pastor, nothing has ever prepared me to do the funeral of a child. Not because I’m feeling any pity for Bryson today. From what you’ve told me, he was a young man of strong faith, and I believe they throwin’ a big “welcome home” party up in heaven for him right about now. Which prompts a few, tearful smiles from the gathering, especially from Julie.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP WILKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But for those of us left behind, we're always left with a single question... “Why?” Folks, there are no easy answers to “why?” All we can do is turn to God and say, “IT don’t understand why this happening. What do I do now?” (looking at Julie) Julie, while none of us can carry your sorrow for you, I want you to know God loves you and so does his family. And my church stands ready to offer you some great big shoulders to cry on any time of the day or night. Julie nods thankfully. Then the Bishop’s eyes are drawn t something o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice, dressed in black, limps up on her cane close eno to listen, but not far enough to be part of the gathering

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The Bishop looks at Dave who is still looking down and is clearly unaware of Clarice’s presence. He thinks for a lo beat, then opens up his Bible.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP WILKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Julie, I don’t know if you’re familiar with the book of Ecclesiastes, but there’s a passage I want to read that I hope you’1l keep close to your heart. (readin

dialogues.speaker: HORE
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP WILKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “It is better to have a partner than go through life alone.”

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: He’s jolted to attention by what he’s hearing, rememberin

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP WILKES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: “Share the work, share the wealth, for if one falls down, the other is there to pick him up.”

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: She’s listening, too, trying to remember something from a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re in church, a dozen years earlier, as a younger Bish Wilkes binds the gold-braided cord around Clarice and Dav shoulders on their wedding day.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP WILKES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “But pity the man who falls and has no one by his side. In bed, two can warm each other at night. But one alone, shivers all night long.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she listens, it all comes flooding back. And so do som tears of regret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bishop continues the reading.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP WILKES
dialogues.text: “By yourself, you are unprotected. But with a partner you can face the worst the world has to offer.” (looking right at Dave) “But even better than that is a cord of three strands because it is not easily broken.” Dave has this unexplainable urge to look away from the Bishop. And when he does, he sees: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he also sees Clarice standing near a tree, looking straight at him. And she gives him a tearful nod.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Dave doesn’t know what to do with his feelings and the Bi has not missed this connection. He turns back to Julie.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP WILKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Julie, what this is sayin’ is that we need a buddy system. One is not only the loneliest number, it’s also the riskiest. It’s our family and friends who make up the first two strands of a three-stranded cord. But God makes up the third. (beat, thinking) And it just occurred to me that maybe God does answer the “why” questions. Maybe the way he does that is by giving us three-stranded cords in our lives to encircle us with love and care... no matter what the world throws at us. And as Julie smiles a watery, thankful smile, Dave is loo more confused that ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the gathering breaks up, Dave is seeing Julie to a hea in the b.g., and the other mourners are scattering to the cars, we FIND Clarice still standing by her tree, thinkin

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It took me awhile, but I think I I’m starting to put the puzzle pieces together. Clarice turns to see Carmen walking up.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dave with Julie Sawyer over there, and you standing way over here. Clarice nods soberly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: (sadly, bitterly) Mama had me move in with her until we can figure out what to do.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: He gettin’ his cake and eatin’ it, too?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I don’t think it’s gone that far yet, but Mama says it’s only a matter of time. Carmen sort of gives a little half-chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Your Mama sure does a lot of talkin’, doesn’t she?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Clarice, I been wonderin’ about something since you first came in for counseling.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: When did your daddy leave?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: He didn’t leave. Mama tossed him out ‘cause she suspected him of cheatin’ on her.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Suspected?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Well, later when I was grown, he admitted to me that he had cheated. He picked up with a lady after he moved out of our house.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: After?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Yeah. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Maybe it’s just me, but it seems like the acorn hasn't fallen very far from the tree. Clarice looks at her for a long, puzzled moment, but then something begins to dawn on her.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. JULIE AND BRYSON’S BUNGALOW - LIVING ROOM - DAY Light is fading out the windows. A small gathering of fam and friends, including Julie’s parents, are mingling over food and conversation in her modest little house. Dave si by himself across the room from where Julie is getting an earful from an ECCENTRIC AUNT with poor funeral etiquette

dialogues.speaker: ECCENTRIC AUNT
dialogues.text: Do you remember the time you had me over to sit when Bryson was two? That little rugrat nearly killed me. I was trying get him out of the tub and he actually bit me. Julie looks like she’s suffocating.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Aunt Janet, but I can’t do this right now. Aunt Janet is offended and crosses off. Julie looks at Da

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you drive me back to the cemetery? Dave looks at her confused for a beat

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just need to spend some time alone there.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MAMA’S BUNGLAOW - CLARICE’S ROOM - DAY Mama is HUMMING as she dusts Clarice’s childhood trophies a bookshelf, when Clarice comes to the door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Do you remember when I won that one, Mama? Mama spins happily to see that her daughter is home.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: (setting trophy back down) I remember every last one of your accomplishments, baby. Clarice crosses in and examines the trophy.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I think this one was after Daddy left because you said it was the first time you saw me smile ina month of Sundays.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: That was good riddance to bad rubbish. Let’s not dredge up all them bad memories. Clarice sets the trophy back and catches Mama by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: No, Mama... let’s. Mama pulls her arm free and gives Clarice a puzzled look.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How come you never told me that Daddy didn’t start havin’ an affair until after you rode his ass out the house?

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: I ain’t havin’ this conversation.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: Because my bedroom drama with your daddy ain’t none or your business. Which pushes a nerve in Clarice. A big nerve.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: (exploding) Excuse me?! I think it is my damn business when you all up in my koolaid about my marriage. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: That’s ‘cause you don’t know men like I do. I’m just lookin’ out for my baby. See what that man did to you, swappin’ gravy with some little white trash biscuit.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: You missin’ the big picture here. My marriage is on the rocks. Who the hell cares what color she is? But Mama is on a roll.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: Men are like nasty ass little chiggers. You got to hold a match to their behinds to get ‘em outta your hair. To keep ‘em from gettin’ under your skin. It’s almost like Clarice is seeing Mama like she’s never her before. Shriveled, sad, bitter, pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Mama, you sound like Jaws when you talkin’ about men. You like a man- eating shark up in here. Who made you so angry and bitter? Was it Grandma Clark? Was it Grandpa? Clarice has flirted with an emotional trip wire. Mama’s e flare for an instant, but then she pushes it all back dow

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: I am a strong, proud, independent black woman. Now Clarice is suddenly feeling pity for her mother.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I don’t know what dark secrets you hidin’ in your heart, but in all your lessons to me about how to be a strong, proud, independent black woman, you left something out.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: You forgot to teach me how to love people. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Panic washes over Mama’s face She has no answer for this. Clarice kisses Mama on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mama, I was wrong to yell at you. And I didn’t mean to disrespect you. But from now on, I’m gonna find out how to do that. I’m gonna start learnin’ how to love my man. And I’m gonna pray for you.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: That it ain’t too late for you to learn how to love people, too. With that, Clarice turns and walks out. Mama tries to “harumph” it all off and return to her dusting chores. Bu beat later, she crumbles onto the bed in private agony.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DAVE’S PANEL VAN - TRAVELING - NIGHT Dave is driving as the city lights dance off Julie’s face she stares blankly out the window. A NEWSTALK HOST is pontificating on the RADIO.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSTALK HOST, (OVER RADIO)
dialogues.text: Now here’s a nice story for a change. The Justice Department's latest national crime survey estimates that murder and attempted murder fell more than forty percent from 1975 through 2006. Wincing, Dave looks over at Julie. He changes the dial to EASY LISTENING station. Something like Clarence Carter’s “SLIP AWAY” is currently in rotation.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Dave, can you drive me up to the overlook?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You mean after the cemetery?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Instead of. I changed my mind. I want to go look at the stars. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dave gives her a smile that says “no problem.”

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DAVE’S PANEL VAN - POV FRONT WINDOW - NIGHT - MOMENT We’re looking over Dave and Julie’s shoulders at a sea of twinkling city lights as the van creeps to a stop at the of an overlook. By this point, something like The Temptations’ “Just My Imagination” is playing on the radi

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I forgot how beautiful this was. Dave is about to turn off the key, when Julie stops him.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can we just leave it playing? I like this song.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Sure. Julie opens the door and gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie is standing at the front of the truck, looking up i the night sky, when Dave joins her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The firmament in all its glory. A billion shining diamond

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bry and I used to come up here and look for The Big Dipper.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Down in the city, I never realized the light blocks all this out. The SILHOUETTE of a pointing hand comes INTO FRAME, and w follow to a familiar cup-shaped constellation.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Look, there it is.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: They are both looking up in wonder. Julie is still in her black funeral dress. Dave notices that she’s shivering. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You’re cold. Here. He takes his suit jacket off and wraps it around her shoulders. She snuggles closer to him for more warmth, putting her arm through his. Just then, she remembers a little ditty and sings a line.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: “Follow the drinking gourd...”

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (smiling) What do you know about the drinkin’ gourd?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Let’s see. I guess that would have been our fourth grade report. He chose the Underground Railroad. They both laugh a little at this. Then there’s a long mom of silence. She begins to weep quietly again.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you remember your inhaler?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (looking at her, confused) Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I was trying to remember the last thing I said to him before his race. That’s what I said to him. “Did you remember your inhaler?” Not “I love you, Bryson.” Not “I’m so proud of you.” Not “You are a bright shining star and I’m so lucky to be your mother.” (tears really coming now) Oh, God, why didn’t I say those things to him? Why? She collapses into his arms again and he holds her for a moment, before she pulls back far enough to look into his face, the starlight glistening on her wet face. Dave’s heart is thumping in his chest as she reaches up a strokes his face. The magnetic connection between them, b of mutual need, is just too strong. She puts her other ha on his face and pulls him into a very chaste kiss. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They look into each other’s eyes again as if testing whet or not that just happened. And then Dave takes her soft features into his hands and pulls her into a more real ki And the world begins SPINNING AROUND THEM as she pulls in close, conforming her body to his and the kiss becomes passionate, hungry. But then, the SPINNING begins to slow we begin to make out a familiar song... “THREE TIMES A LA playing on the car radio. And then we are no longer swirling around them, but STOPP just as Dave breaks the kiss and pulls away from her. His eyes are drawn to the car window and the memory of that s

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dave?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (frozen with guilt) I’m sorry. I just can’t do this. For more reasons than I can count.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: It's my fault. I was just trying to feel something, anything besides this big black hole in my heart.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I know you do, Julie. And Lord knows, you deserve that. But not this way. Not with me. We both been flirtin’ with a fire that gonna only end up burnin’ a lot of people. Julie somehow musters a smile through her tears.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: See, you’re doing it to me again. The reason I want you so badly is the reason I can’t have you. Because you’re a gentleman. The most gentle man I’ve ever met. And as he smiles through his own tears and wipes hers awa we begin HEARING his remembering voice once more.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Until that moment, I don’t think I'd ever felt like a true man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Dave enters in his funeral clothes, he’s surprised to see Clarice there, still in her funeral dress, sitting in lamp light, reading a Bible. Dave nods

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Clarice, I need to --

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: No, Dave, let me go first Dave. Please. and sits on the arm of the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I been round and round with my heart today, and I want you to know two things. First, Mama has lost her voting privileges in this marriage.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Damn. That’s a big one.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: (fighting back tears) And second. I’m home. No matter what you decide to do, I’m not giving up on this marriage until it’s dead. Or until we are.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (chokes back his emotions) I was about to tell you the same thing. She rushes into his open arms and they hold each other li they haven’t held each other in a long, long time.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I used to beat my head against the wall, tryin’ to figure out what my purpose was. And I looked in a lot of wrong places to find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re HIGH ABOVE the diamond, as if watching from heaven, a little league game is in its final moments. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The bleachers are packed with CHEERING fans, penants have been hung all around, and some Dad PLAY-BY-PLAY MAN is on microphone.

dialogues.speaker: PLAY-BY-PLAY MAN, (OVER P.A.)
dialogues.text: East Side is down to its final out with the score tied at 5. Looks like this playoff game may be goin’ to extra innings, ya’ll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carlos is leading off at third base while Dave is coachin third, Brock is coaching first, and the rest of the East team is biting their nails in the dugout.

dialogues.speaker: PLAY-BY-PLAY MAN, (OVER P.A.)
dialogues.text: The batter is Darius Jones. As Darius steps up to the plate, the opposing infielders up to play the bunt. Dave gives him a shout-out.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: They playin’ the bunt, D. Hit it hard. You King Kong up in this piece. Dave gives hima sign. Darius wags his head “okay.”

dialogues.speaker: THE BLEACHERS
dialogues.text: Clarice is sitting in the front row. She shakes a little NOISE-MAKER.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: Whoo hoo! Pitcher’s got a rubber arm! And then we'll ADJUST to FIND Darnell, sitting not too fa away, looking good. Looking clean. No forties. No Ho’s.

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: Come on, boy. Show me the money!

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The opposing pitcher goes into his windup, and here comes pitch, and Darius talks the biggest swing of his life -- FOUL BALL. The CROWD MOANS.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: That’s all right, son. You got ‘em scared now. Dave gives him another sign. Darius wags his head again. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The opposing first and third basemen play back a little deeper. The pitcher winds and fires it in again. But this time, Carlos begins dashing home and Darius squares aroun bunt, and lays down the perfect little dribbler which rol right past Carlos as he slides in home for the winning ru

dialogues.speaker: PLAY-BY-PLAY MAN, (OVER P.A.)
dialogues.text: It’s a squeeze play. Carlos Gooden slides home safe. East Side Wins! East Side wins!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a ROAR goes up in the bleachers, the East Side boys al pour out of the dugout and pile on Carlos at home plate. dirty, dusty human pyramid. Dave and Brock run in and jump on the pile. Lots of high- fives and AD LIBBED celebrations.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But if you want to know the purpose of a thing, you can’t ask the thing to tell you. A car doesn’t know why it’s a car. Only the manufacturer knows what it was made to do. And I guess that’s the way it is with God. Darnell races out of the bleachers and to home plate, pul Carlos from the bottom of the pile -- givin’ him a high f followed by a hug. And as the rest of the stands empty, Clarice is content t watch from here. But something tells her to turn around. And when she does, she sees Julie sitting at the top of t stands all by herself. They exchange a nod which doesn’t all is forgiven -- but that a truce has been declared.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He didn’t just make Dave Johnson to be a husband, or a coach, or a friend, or a daddy. Those are just roles. Not who I am as a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darnell is examing Carlos’ glove. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: You got to put some oil over here or the laces gonna break. (beat, then) I had my laces break in a game once. Ball popped right out. Ain’t nobody ever told me about oilin’ a glove.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: I‘ll remember that. Hey, Dad, you wanna hit some me pop flies? Darnell looks at his son, breaking out in a broad smile.

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: Let’s do it.

dialogues.speaker: BLEACHERS
dialogues.text: Brock climbs the last few steps and straddles the row rig below Julie. She looks a little melancholy.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Thanks for inviting me today, Brock. It’s nice to be out in the sunshine for a change. Brock smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: I thought I should offer to walk you to your car. This ain’t the safest neighborhood, you know. Now Julie musters a little smile.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I'd like that.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: By the way, I don’t have a date for the team party. You interested?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: (looking uncomfortable) I don’t think I better. It’s still too weird. But thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BROCK
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: But I wouldn’t mind coffee later. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Which perks Brock right up.

dialogues.speaker: DUGOUT
dialogues.text: As Dave packs up the gear, Clarice watches from the bench

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: All these years, I never knew you were such a good coach. You oughta do more of it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (smiling) Thanks, Boo.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: I think you gonna make a pretty good daddy someday, too. He looks at her, trying not to read too much into it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I hope so.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: In fact, try about seven and a half months from now. And as Dave's jaw drops and Clarice smiles a big happy sm and Dave takes her into his arms, we’ll PULL UP and BACK that big heavenly WIDE SHOT and look down on cords of thr strands happening all over the field.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But I guess sometimes God has to let life turn you upside down... so can learn how to live right side up. FADE OUT.
